The first day, March 21st, will feature a free public lecture provided by Robert Glennon, law professor and author of "America's Water Crisis and What to Do About It."  This event will also feature Congressman Jay Inslee and a special video message from famed water activist Alexandra Cousteau.  The night will also include a blessing provided by representatives of the Duwamish Tribe.  Preceding the lecture, there will be a Water Resource Fair.  Several government and community organizations will have information tables while people enjoy refreshments and jazz music.

Project Title: Willow and 42nd St Beautification and Litter Deterrent
Project Description: The roundabout at 42nd and Willow is in need of a face lift.  It is in a high foot and vehicle traffic area, full of weeds, and a magnet for litter.  This spring, the Willow Street Neighbors will till the soil and remove invasive species (grass, English ivy, shopping carts).  The soil will be amended with compost and hardy, drought-tolerant plant species and a new tree will be added.  Plants will be chosen for both their beauty and their low-maintenance.  This beautification effort will foster a renewed sense of community, ownership and responsibility.

The Friends of Plum Tree Park will continue their commitment to improve the park by adding new plants and fruit bearing trees.  This project will build a sense of community and collective responsibility as neighbors work together to enhance the site.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Organization Name: FREMONT ABBEY ARTS CENTER (ARTWERKS DBA FREMONT ABBEY)
Project Description: Project will renovate our kitchen to meet public health and safety code and purchase commercial kitchen equipment in order to create a community kitchen and other programs for the neighborhood.

On Saturday, April 9th, Crown Hill neighbors will be invited to participate in a three hour exploration of their community, aptly named the Crown Hill Hood Hunt.  Participants will receive maps marked with several locations, minus the street names and will be expected to make their way to the locations and answer questions at each stop.  Everyone will gather at the community center after the hunt to share stories, enjoy refreshments and connect as a community.  Matching Fund supported events are funded on a one-time only basis and must be free to the public.

The Crown Hill Center is a focal point for the community. The roof that provides the shelter for the vast array of community and arts activities that occur in the building is in desperate need of recovering. In addition to putting a roof over the existing community and arts space, this project expands the usable community space at Crown Hill Center.

With funding from the Neighborhood Matching Fund Program, we will address critical physical improvement projects in the newly purchased Ethiopian Community Center in Southeast Seattle. These health and safety improvements include renovation of the flat tar roof and improvements to facility bathrooms that will bring them up to current code.

Project Title: The New Camp Long Community Collaboration Project (The New CCC Project)
Project Description: To establish a challenge course program that is a useful tool for local organizations to develop youth skills and acts as a vehicle for establishing strong partnerships between local organizations.

The project will help build community, inspire change, and promote healthy transportation habits. Through community engagement the project will help businesses and schools adopt no-idling practices, walking school buses and bike to school programs to improve air quality, save people money, and reduce carbon pollution.

As part of the City of Seattle’s Spring Clean the Letitia Neighborhood Group will be accomplishing several projects throughout the community.  On Sunday, May 22nd from noon until 3:00 p.m. they will be picking up litter, weeding and adding plants in the street right of way on Letitia Avenue South between S. Charleston and S. Genesee.  The neighborhood has committed to maintaining these areas.  The entire community will be positively impacted by these improvements.  Clean streets and well tended landscapes make residents feel better about where the live and teach visitors to respect the community as well.  A neighborhood barbeque will follow the event.  SDOT has approved the project.

Project Title: Electricidad Performance and Audience Talk Back and Dinner
Project Description: The Electricidad Steering Committee will sponsor a free performance of Luis Alfaros’ adaption of the Sophocles play “Electra” which is set in a contemporary immigrant, primarily Hispanic neighborhood in East Los Angeles.  A setting very much like South Park.  The play will be followed by an open-forum discussion and a dinner, catered by a local restaurant.  The event will be on Thursday, May 26 from 6:00-10:00 p.m. at the South Park Community Center.  The viewing of the play and the community discussion will help neighborhood youth to see the theatre as a positive vehicle to express their thoughts and emotions.  After the event, efforts will be made to involve the youth in creating their own theatre as a means of cultural expression. Events are one time only and free to the public.

Project Title: Outreach with Camel, Othello Park International Music and Art Festival
Project Description: The Othello Park International Music and Art Festival is in its fourth year and has grown from 300 participants to 1,000.  This diverse, family friendly event includes music, dance, local vendors and hands on art projects.  In order to draw more families and to connect with their new East African neighbors, the Alliance plans to include a camel as part of the festivities this year.  Attendees will have an opportunity to view the camel on Saturday, August 21 between noon and 5:00 p.m. at the Holly Park Community Church, 4308 South Othello Street.  The participation of the church this year extends the event to both sides of the street.  Neighborhood Matching Fund supported events are funded on a one-time only basis and are free and open to the public.

Project Title: Spring into Health - Eritrean Health Fair May 7, 2011
Project Description: On Saturday, May 7 the Hope Eritrean Social Services will partner with the City of Seattle and Regional Medical Library to host the fourth annual Eritrean Community Health Fair at the Kidisti Sillassie Orthodox Church located at 12327 – 15th Avenue NE.  The event runs from 10 a.m. until 4 p.m. and will feature workshops, free health screenings, and tips on exercise and healthy eating.  The program will be offered in both English and Tigrinya.  The goal of this event is to increase personal health awareness and to inspire participants to make positive behavior changes.

B.O.O.M. You're Up!  Is a free youth summit on May 14, 2011 at the Southwest Community Center, from 11 a.m. - 4 p.m.  The theme and tagline of the event are "youth Leading Change: We Matter" and "Talk about it.  Be about it."  These make clear our mission of empowering youth to take action in their communities and be the change they want to see.  We intend to bring together 150-200 youth ages 13-19 living in the Southwest Seattle area for the purpose of discussing the issues that face their community and act on concrete changes they want to see in their neighborhood.  Participants will be given opportunities to take action towards these changes and voice their ideas to Mayor Mike McGinn.  The event will celebrate what they love about the places they live through creative expression and performances by local artists as well as provide a safe space to focus existing passions into creative actions.  



Youth and adult facilitated workshops will inform participants about Food Justice, Violence Prevention, Systems of Power and Oppression, and Navigating College/Job Application Process.

Project Title: Rainier Vista Bridge to Beach Clean Up
Project Description: On Sunday, May 1, 2011 from 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. approximately 30 youth will participate in a coordinated effort to remove graffiti and pick up litter along Martin Luther King Jr. Way S from South Lucille Street to S Juneau.  Litter will be removed from the streets and traffic circles.  The project will conclude with a community celebration at the Rainier Vista Boys and Girls Club (4520 MLK Jr. Way S) where the volunteers will be recognized for their efforts.  This project will enhance the feeling of community pride and collective responsibility in the neighborhood.

This project will be one part of a monthly presentation of Latino films, highlighting the diversity in this under-appreciated genre.  Specifically, on May 28th, we will present the book, "On Location in Cuba" by Ann Marie Stock in conjunction with a film presentation.  Ms Stock will be bringing a film from Cuba to help highlight the points about filmmaking she makes in her book, and help to inform the local community about the unique approach the Cuban people have to filmmaking.

Project Title: 2011 White Center Business District Mixer & Planter Box Maintenance Project
Organization Name: Mixer Planning and Planter Boxes Maintenance Committee
Project Description: White Center community members will come together to host 5 business mixer meetings and technical assistance seminar for the business community. In addition, community volunteers will repair and replant planter boxes throughout the White Center Business District.

Three years ago South Park residents were interested in a neighborhood community kitchen but determined it was not feasible at the time. This year a partnership between Sea Mar Community Health Centers, the REACH Coalition of King County, Solid Ground (Lettuce Link at Marra Farm), Parks and Recreation (South Park Community Center), South Park residents, including parents of children enrolled in the Head Start Program, and other volunteers is providing the opportunity to plan and implement a community kitchen pilot project, and assess its feasibility and sustainability. Produce supplied by Marra Farm will drive the seasonal menus for the monthly community kitchens. We aim to increase access to healthy foods and provide food literacy and meal planning education. The kitchens will be open to all residents over an eight month period, free of charge, with an option to attend all sessions as a series. Outreach will be done at the South Park Community Center, Info Center, Library and Concord International Elementary.

Project Title: Ballard Traffic Circle Beautification at 28th and 59th
Organization Name: Ballard Traffic Circle Beautification at 59th Ave NW and 28th Ave
Project Description: Small Sparks funds will be used for the beautification of the traffic circle at 59th NW and NW 28th Avenue.  Volunteers will remove dead shrubbery, weeds and old dirt.  New soil and compost will be added along with plants/shrubs and flowers.  This improvement will give neighbors the opportunity to work together to beautify the neighborhood.  SDOT has given their approval to proceed.

The groundbreaking ceremony for the new South Park Bridge will be on Thursday, May 5.  South Park Arts will leverage the attendance from that event by hosting a Cinco de Mayo celebration for the neighborhood.  There will be a live arts event, great music, face painting and a crafts tent.  This is a perfect opportunity for South Park Arts to build community among neighbors who are interested in beautifying their urban village.  Activities will take place from 5:00 p.m. to 8:30 p.m. at 14th Avenue South and South Cloverdale.  Neighborhood Matching Fund events are funded on a one-time only basis and are free to the public.

Project Title: A Salute to Youth on the Move for Education
Project Description: This is a community-wide event to promote the value of education to young people and to celebrate the youth who have chosen to focus on their education and refrain from participating in gang violence and other antisocial behavior.  In recognition of Flag Day, the youth will be invited to write an essay on what America means to them.  These essays will be published and made available on line and in the local public libraries.  At least 500 copies will be printed.  There will also be a community parade on Saturday, June 11th starting at 11:00 a.m.  The parade will begin at 22nd Avenue South and S. Lane street and will end at Pratt Park, where students will be invited to read their essays.  This is a great way to honor these young people for building community pride through good citizenship.

Project Title: El Centro de la Raza Seismic and Plumbing Safety and System Upgrades
Project Description: Complete seismic and plumbing upgrades to the historic El Centro de la Raza building to maintain safety and health of building users. El Centro provided 32 community programs and human services to 23,565 mostly low-income people in 2010, community meeting and event space, and serves as a hub for the Latino community.

Organization Name: Gay, Lesbian, and Straight Education Network Washington State
Project Description: On Friday, June 24th, from 6:00-11:00 p.m. a Youth Pride Dance will be held at Pravda Studios, located at 1406 – 10th Avenue. This event is intended to give the under 21 community of LGBTQ youth and their allies a safe and fun way to participate in Seattle’s Pride weekend.  Pride’s theme this year is “Be You. Be Proud. Express Yourself!”  The Youth Pride Dance steering committee and its many volunteers honor this theme by allowing youth a safe place to celebrate themselves.  Youth tend to be excluded from a majority of the Pride Weekend events as most of the activities target adults.  This event will start a tradition of having a safe place for youth to gather and celebrate their identities while feeling included in the greater LGBT community. Youth are actively involved in the planning of the dance to further cultivate a sense of community activism.

Hello Earth Day Community Preparedness event will bring together different community groups on April 16 to work together on an important Earth Day project.  Over the past three years, Wallingford neighbors have developed a set of Community Preparedness Hubs to respond to earthquakes and other emergencies at a local level.  With the help of the Office of Emergency Management, Wallingford Community Preparedness has trained radio operators, and identified first aid and search and rescue groups in several blocks.  This event will increase awareness of the local program and bring more neighbors into it to demonstrate how they can play a role in local preparedness.  The tent and supplies will be housed at the Wallingford Senior Center post-event.

Residents of the NewHolly community will convene a series of focus groups to discuss how far the community has come in meeting the HUD HOPE VI goals.  Each focus group will represent a different community voice, i.e., ethnic group, housing option or age.  Areas of concern will include, what people like or dislike about NewHolly, how do people interact with neighbors, what do they see as a successful community, and in what ways they may want to change NewHolly, and be involved in that change.  Results of the focus groups will be communicated at a subsequent neighborhood event, where we all can decide what we want to do with the feedback.

Project Title: Seward Park Centennial Celebration - Hydroplane Display
Project Description: As Seward Park celebrates its 100th anniversary, the Centennial Celebration Committee is planning a series of neighborhood events that will culminate in a weekend festival July 15 – 17, 2011.  The event will feature many human and natural uses of the park throughout its history, such as a vintage car show, a fashion shown, a promenade around the lower loop road and a hydroplane display.  Families will be able to view the boats up close and learn how they have become faster, safer and more fuel efficient over the years.  The boats can be viewed Saturday, July 16th from 10:00 a.m. until 4:00 p.m.  Neighborhood Matching Fund supported events are funded on a one time only basis and are free to the public.  The Parks Department has approved the project.

The Colman Neighborhood Association will sponsor the community gathering “Soop and Kookies” on Sunday, May 1 from 2-6 p.m. at the Children’s Play Garden located at 24th Avenue S and S Massachusetts.  Chefs will lead teams of soup makers and cookie bakers.  Neighborhood histories will be shared and a map will be developed to identify dog walkers, knitters, football lovers and other interest groups.  This event, rather than a workshop or a conference is designed to attract neighbors who have not participated in the past and to build the trust necessary to cooperate positively on neighborhood improvement projects and concerns.  Events are funded on a one-time only basis and must be free and open to the public.  A permit for use of the park is required.

Project Title: YOUTH ARTS COMPENDIUM - The World in 16 pages
Project Description: Unified Outreach, a nonprofit arts organization that specializes in developing the artistic talents of minority youth, will work with other community partners to produce a 16 page Youth Arts Compendium, featuring youth created cartoon strips, graphics, poems, photographs, current event articles and public announcements.  Youth ages ten to eighteen will be invited to submit their work, through June 1st for inclusion in a publication that will be distributed city-wide.  Submittal requests will be advertised via the internet on the official Unified Outreach website, social media and press releases to local media.  Additional hard copy requests for submittals will be posted at community centers and libraries.  The art director and a committee of youth judges will decide what submittals will be used.  Every effort will be made to use all of the work submitted for the project.  A celebration of the artist’s work will be held on July 2, 2011; from noon – 3 p.m. in the Ginomai Art Center/Unified Outreach meeting hall located at 4401 – 42nd Ave SW, West Seattle, 98106.  Approximately 10,000 copies will be produced and distributed throughout Seattle.  The City of Seattle will receive 50 copies.

The annual festival works to promote healthy lifestyles by providing education and information about nutrition, dental, mental, physical health to all people in our community.  Education and Information is provided by professionals and volunteers primarily from the Sickle Cell community throughout Washington State.  Our goal is to use their story and experiences to empower others to be more aware of their personal health conditions.



The Health Eating, Health Living Fair will be held September 10, 2011 11 a.m. – 2 p.m. at Seward Park.  Appropriate Parks permits must be secured.

Friends of Yesler Swamp will complete environmental mitigation,engineering,and Phase 1 construction of a boardwalk through Yesler Swamp, one of Seattle's few remaining wooded swamps. This boardwalk will be part of a permanent, handicapped-accessible trail through this unique natural area.

Flo Ware Day is an annual event co-sponsored by the Leschi Community Council, Seattle Parks Department and the Seattle Police Department.  It is designed to honor Flo Ware, an African American community activist who was instrumental in the fight for justice in Seattle.  The celebration will be Saturday, May 14 from 11:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. at the park named in her honor, located at 28th Avenue South and South Jackson Street.  The event will include food, beverages, information booths, live music performances and acting.  There will be games and face painting for the kids.  Events are funded on a one time only basis and must be free and open to the public.  A permit for use of the park is required.
Installation of a neighborhood identification sign at NE 65th St, north side at Sand Point Way NE and supplied by Seattle Department of Transportation.

Organization Name: Growing Food Growing Community Greenhouse Project
Project Description: Volunteers will volunteer to help grow thousands of veggie starts in a neighbor's greenhouse for Lettuce Link (a project of Solid Ground), which distributes the starts to P-Patch gardeners who grow the vegetables and donate them to area food banks. This year 25 volunteers will spend about an hour a week each at the greenhouse.  This project serves an important social good, while also building community and increasing knowledge of how to grow food.  Each year our request for volunteers is open to the public.  Many of this year's volunteers have volunteered in the past, and they all love to their hands dirty.  This is an ongoing, year-round project, though most of the heavy lifting comes during the actual growing season.

On Saturday, April 30th the community is invited to a night of multicultural, multigenerational dancing at the Central Area Senior Center, at 500 – 30th Avenue South from 6 to 10 p.m.  Neighbors of different ethnic groups and ages will teach each other their dances, including Hip Hop, Line Dancing, Zumba, Chicago Style Stepping, Native American Friendship Dance, Tinikling and West African Dance.  Seven dance lessons will be presented, followed by all-out dancing.  This event is following on the heels of a very successful dance party that was held in Southeast Seattle in November.  As one participant who attended the last dance party said, "Changing the world one dance party at a time".  Events are funded on a one-time only basis and must be free and open to the public.  The applicant organization is responsible for obtaining the required permits and observing all regulations relative to the serving of alcohol.  A copy of the permit must be provided to the Department of Neighborhoods at least 48 hours prior to the event.

Project Title: Valley Vibes, Community Concert & Conversation Series
Project Description: An innovative new pilot series, Valley Vibes will be held at the Rainier Valley Cultural Center during 2010-2012. Featuring six evenings of jazz music, played by emerging and established talents, each concert will be followed by a lecture/conversation involving performing artists, audience members, and invited speakers.

To teach the Tibetan language, culture, and traditional Tibetan music and dance on a weekly basis to children 5-14 in our community, to all children interested, culmininating in public performances at venues such as the Seattle Center (Tibet Fest, part of the Festal series), the Greenwood Sr. Center, Egan Hall, and at other community-wide events.

The Seattle Area Happiness Initiative seeks support to conduct a scientific well-being survey of Seattle residents and separate the data by neighborhood, allowing for active engagement by citizens. We also seek support to create two neighborhood projects based on the nine key domains of well-being, outlined in this document.

A day in the life of America's most diverse zip code, recorded by poets and photographers, over a 24-hour period on Wednesday, October 5, 2011. The Project was developed by writer Nancy Rawles, Paul Nelson, Director of SPLAB (Spoken Word Lab) in Columbia City and a group of neighbors wanting to document our cultural diversity.

Project Title: Legacy, Community and Connections: Exploring Seattle's Nihonmachi
Project Description: The Wing Luke Museum of the Asian Pacific American Experience (The Wing) will preserve, inventory and interpret historic materials and artifacts from the Higo Variety Store and create an accompanying exhibit (to be presented at the Wing in late 2011) and a traveling educational display.
Storefronts Seattle promotes neighborhood vitality by bringing art and creative enterprise to available storefronts in Chinatown-International District and Pioneer Square.

The project will serve 72 Somali youth, and help them with leadership skills through soccer, which is an international sport that touches many cultures. This project will fill a void that has been in the community, and this will help us make our youth the focal point of community engagement issues, since they tend to be left out in so many ways.
To renovate our well-used, well-loved west playground's play equipment to create a safe, engaging and colorful place for children of the school and local community.

In the last 1960s and early 70s Seattle Community Colleges (SCC) refused to hire Asian Americans in administrative positions because they were “over qualified.”  Student activists from the Oriental Student Union (OSU) at SCC protested this action and eventually closed the SCC Administration Building on February 9 and again on March 2, 1971.  This February and March are the 40th anniversary of those demonstrations.  Student activists from the OSU of 40 years ago will retell the story of the event, and show how the actions of a few helped start a whole movement that still lives today.  The group will develop a PowerPoint presentation, recruit and organize presenters, design a flyer and outreach strategy to draw today’s students and community members to the presentation, organize and implement event logistics, and make a video record of the event.

Friends of South Lake Union SLU Dog Park, which was conceived at a neighborhood meeting in August attended by about 30 SLU resident dog owners, will initiate a campaign to solicit community support and input for the planning and development of an off-leash dog park in SLU.  The project will include an information campaign to inform SLU residents about our organization through community meetings, distribution of flyers and the maintenance of a SLU Dog Park website.  The project will also solicit input regarding the location and design of the off-leash dog park, recruit volunteers and solicit community contributions to develop the park.  Friends of SLU Dog Park volunteers will also work with COLA and city officials to seek potential sites and plans for an off-leash park for SLU resident dogs.

Provide increased and culturally appropriate child, family and community gathering and activity space including a rain or shine shelter with storage, tables, and benches for a meeting/community circle, telling stories, reading poetry, performances, music, neighborhood meetings and cultural exchanges; with lighting and minor landscaping.

Project Title: Capitol Hill Emergency Radio Communications Hubs
Project Description: Capitol Hill Preparedness People (ChiPP) will help local residents prepare themselves for disaster, equip and maintain three emergency radio communications hub locations on Capitol Hill; and train neighbors to volunteer at the designated communications hub sites.

Telling Our Westside Stories: Land, Work, Home is an oral history project of the Southwest Seattle Historical Society/Log House Museum. Youth of the Duwamish Peninsula will interview elders and interpret the history of their neighborhoods through a traveling, interactive exhibit and map, featuring audio clips from the interviews.

Project Title: Georgetown Carnival: Art, Music and More!
Project Description: A community building event celebrating Georgetown's creative diversity by showcasing cultural activities of resident visual and performing artists and locally-owned small businesses. This free event will attract visitors citywide and is critical in unifying a neighborhood isolated and divided by multiple transportation projects planned throughout 2011.
The Gateway project will engage neighbors to develop a plan and initial improvements to enhance the walkability and safety of the main southern connection between Sunset Hill and Shilshole.

The Genesee-Schmitz Neighborhood Council (GSNC) will implement a series of discrete projects and events, all with a common goal: engaging the residents in our area in the efforts of the GSNC, but more importantly creating a cohesive community and neighborhood within our geographical area.

Project Title: Phinney Neighborhood Center Stairway and Community Plaza
Project Description: As part of a larger renovation of the Phinney Neighborhood Center, we plan to open up access from Phinney Ave with the addition of a new concrete stairway and a small community plaza, carved out of the current parking lot.

The goal of this project is to provide funding and focused attention on the Adventure Play area and the Children's Garden components of the planned Maple Leaf Family Terrace creation as part of the Maple Leaf Reservoir Project. We are seeking $100,000 in matching funds from the Large Project Fund.

Vision Greenwood Park (VGP) will construct a multi-sport courtyard in Greenwood Park to provide much-needed recreation activities for teens and young adults. This innovative facility will use a new style of sports equipment that incorporates basketball and soccer goals at the ends of an open court to maximize flexibility and uses of the space.

Project Title: Connecting Communities through Web/TV Technology Programming
Project Description: The Multimedia Resource and Training Institute (MMRTI) proposes to augment Seattle's public access television capabilities by providing free access to a state-of-the-art video studio, production classes and Web distribution. This project will give a voice to underrepresented populations through high quality videos created by and for their communities.

As part of a unique partnership between youth, businesses and residents in the Jackson Street community, students from Washington Middle School will research the history Jackson Street and with the assistance of a teaching artist from Coyote Central, will transform the conversations and history onto panel murals.  The panels will be painted, sealed and displayed at a property owned by the Central Area Development Association, located at 1706 S. Jackson Street.  Youth from the Garfield and Madrona neighborhoods will design and install their own murals, creating a “Corridor of Peace”.  Property owners have agreed to maintain the murals and applicant groups must obtain the necessary street use permits if installation requires egress into the street right-of-way.  A copy of the permit must be presented to the Department of Neighborhoods prior to any work beginning on the site.

Project Title: Bring the Ring Back to Ballard
Project Description: Bring the Ring Back to Ballard will install an automatic, programmable mechanism in Ballard's existing historic bell structure, located at the corner of 22nd Ave NW and Ballard Ave NW. The bell will ring regularly and on demand for special occasions. We will have a public celebration to honor the return of the bell's ring to Ballard.

The project goal is to help Somali refugee youth build self esteem and better connect with the community at large.  To accomplish this aim, youth will be trained in computer 3D and animation.  They will showcase their skills at a community gathering and then will offer lessons to their parents and other community youth.  Somali youth have a difficult time adjusting to western culture and this will allow them to build confidence and develop leadership skills.  At the same time they will strengthen their relationships with their parents and elders who will be teaching them to perform culturally relevant dances and how to construct their costumes.  Project outcomes include two community cultural performances, a showcase of 3D and animation skills and computer classes for adults and youths led by the newly trained teens.

This project will renovate the playground at Salmon Bay School into an Autism Spectrum Disorder-friendly playspace which also serves the needs of younger children, enhances the site so that it is a neighborhood asset, and educates the public about the importance of early intervention for children with ASD.  Neighborhood Matching Fund dollars will be used for construction elements.

Project Title: Corridor of Peace 23rd and Cherry Street
Project Description: As part of a growing collaboration between youth, schools, the business community and residents, historic murals will be installed on the Coyote Building on the corner of 23rd and E Cherry.  Community youth will research the history of the Garfield community and with the assistance of a teaching artist will transform those conversations into panel murals.  The youth will also design a mobile art element to signify community unity, alcohol and drug-free youth and peace.  Youth from the Madrona and Jackson Street communities will create their own murals to be installed along this “Corridor of Peace”.  The building owner has agreed to maintain the murals and the applicant group must obtain the necessary street use permits if installation requires egress into the street right-of-way.  A copy of the permit must be presented to the Department of Neighborhoods prior to any work beginning on the site.

Project Title: First Hill Performance Project: Red Shoes
Project Description: A neighborhood-wide collaborative site specific performance project on First Hill - a collaboration between the Frye Art Museum, St. James Cathedral and multi-art performance ensemble Degenerate Art Ensemble. The project will stage performances in locations throughout the district over a period of a month.

As part of a unique partnership between youth, businesses and residents in the Madrona community, students will research the history of the intersection of 23rd and Union.  With the assistance of an artist, those conversations will be transformed into panel murals and installed on the Thompson Building.  Youth will also design a mobile art element to signify community unity, alcohol and drug-free youth, and peace.  Youth from the neighborhoods surrounding Garfield High School and Washington Middle School will design and install their own murals, creating a “Corridor of Peace”.  Property owners have agreed to maintain the murals and applicant groups must obtain the necessary street use permits if installation requires egress into the street right-of-way.  A copy of the permit must be presented to the Department of Neighborhoods prior to any work beginning on the site.

Project Title: Broadview Bitter Lake Neighbor Appreciation Day Community Gathering
Project Description: This neighborhood is looking forward to major City government projects including Linden Complete Streets funding, major re-development of our sewers, turning the Bitter Lake Reservoir into a park-like atmosphere, inclusive of a P-Patch, and work is underway on the update of our 1999 Neighborhood Master Plan. The Broadview Community Council is providing leadership to bring a number of neighborhood organizations and City representatives to our Community Center on Neighbor Appreciation Day, February 12, to showcase what is happening and to sign up neighbors for participating within the community. We understand there is a good possibility that the Mayor will visit during our event. We currently have a highly populated Hub Urban Village, about 5,000 residents, and this event will occur at the principal gathering place for these apartment and condominium dwellers. However, all Broadview residents will be invited through marketing with posters, flyers, and announcements. We need to develop community, spread the word about all of these exciting projects, and energize our residents to participate in community development.

The project is part of a public art installation, youth education, and online historic preservation of the black music tradition and culture in the Central District.  Pratt Fine Arts Center is matching local students with four community artists to design, create and install four installations celebrating four genres of music; jazz, funk, soul/gospel, and hip hop.  A fifth installation will be a historic timeline of music in the Central District.  Installations will be erected with wood and provide a three dimensional quality to the work.  



Installations will honor and highlight musicians from each genre.  Students will research the history of each genre and conduct personal interviews with the musicians.  In addition, a phone line will allow people to listen to relevant music and leave messages with stories from the past about the musical scene in the Central District.  These stories will be archived on the Jackson Place Community Council website.

The Capitol Hill Community Council seeks to make 12th Avenue East safer to cross by using a public engagement process to develop and implement a traffic management plan that would slow traffic and make crossing pedestrians and bicyclists more visible to drivers.  The goal is to make small pedestrian and bicycle friendly physical improvements as identified in the planning process.  Successful outcomes include physical improvements to 12th Avenue as well as a traffic management plan.

The Leadership Academy for Community Leaders is a ten session training to provide residents of South Park with the tools necessary to develop successful strategies to address community issues. Participants will learn how to link personal relationships to communty change, and will develop an understanding of the need to act collectively. Upon completion of the training, the new leaders will do a community assesment, prioritize their issues and develop and implement a community project.  They will receive coaching, mentoring and money for supplies and equipment.

Project Title: Storage Boxes for Emergency Communications Bags (the West Seattle Hubs)
Project Description: Purchase four storage "joboxes" to store emergency communication equipment in parks that have been designated Neighborhood Emergency Communication Hub locations. The storage boxes would make the equipment easily available to the Hub leaders so that the closest trained personnel can get the equipment set up after a disaster.

The funds will be used to restore a water souce to an existing garden irrigation system at the McNae Triangle Park in the Madison Park Community. The City of Seattle Department of Transportation has removed the water meter that services the irrigation system at the McNae Triangle Park and will not be replacing the meter.

Montake community residents will hire a contractor to build a gravel path that will enhance the park with a comfortable and scenic walking alternative for pedestrians. Native plants will also be installed to complete the plan for the urban park.  This is a significant step in a continued effort by the community to restore and maintain this green space that is so essential to the neighborhood.

Project Title: Othello Park Enhancement Project - Phase II
Project Description: Othello Park is an important asset to a rapidly changing and diverse community. This project seeks to build on 2011 levy-funded lighting and safety improvements. Othello Park Enhancement project - Phase II will install a stage for community events, expand playground area, and build entry plazas to increase safety and usability of the Park.

Project Title: Rainier Beach Urban Farm and Wetlands Project
Project Description: With community support the  Friends of Atlantic City Nursery  will transform a surplus Parks Department facility into a working organic farm and demonstration wetlands restoration site. This award will support planning and design review for development of the Rainier Beach Urban Farm and Wetlands project.

The Southeast Seattle Community Youth Orchestra will engage Teaching Artists representative of the cultural diversity of Southeast Seattle by inviting them to share their traditional styles of music as well as their rich cultural histories with the young members of the Orchestra. The project will conclude with a community concert of Ethnic Artists in August 2013 that will feature fusion music written by the students in collaboration with their instructors and visiting Ethnic Teaching Artists.

Project Title: B.F. Day Playground Project - Phase 1 Construction
Project Description: A new play structure will be constructed and the existing sports court will be updated at B.F. Day Elementary School. This play structure will benefit students, the school and neighborhood especially because it is the only public play equipment in the Fremont neighborhood.

Interim CDA will build a Neighborhood Cookery in the Danny Woo Garden on property that is privately owned by the Woo Family. The Neighborhood Cookery will be a structure that will contain a cooking element and a classroom. The Cookery will be utilized as both an educational facility and a congregation point for gardeners, children, youth and residents of the International District.

Project Title: Nights at the Neptune: A People's Theatre Joint
Project Description: Seattle Theatre Group will make the professionally staffed Neptune Theatre in the University District available to artists and community organizations ten times per year at no charge. These ten engagements will include two days of access: one for rehearsal and one for presentation. The content will be the responsibility of the artists, but the program will emphasize access for artists concerned with issues of race, social justice, and youth. Presentations will be offered to the public for free.

Project Title: Jimi Hendrix Park: Little Wing Project
Organization Name: Friends of Jimi Hendrix Park Committee
Project Description: The Friends of Jimi Hendrix Park Committee (`FOJHP`) seeks funding for the first phase of construction (the “Little Wing” phase) of Jimi Hendrix Park. The proposed improvements include an entry staircase, concrete seat walls, plantings, site furniture, signage, irrigation and site paving; along with funding for demolition, electrical and drainage work.  This project is being supported with $500,000 in funding from the Parks Open Space Levy.

Organization Name: South Park Information and Resource Center SPIARC
Project Description: ELLA (Empowering Latina Leaders to Action) is a project that aims to empower a group of 20 Latina immigrant women from South Park  with a double mission of promoting personal transformation and building community power for social and economic justice. This pilot project, will explore how ELLA students engage and learn when receiving English instruction through a technology-based and community-centered approach.

A series of 4 murals will be painted in the Capitol Hill neighborhood that showcase the great art that Seattle has to offer.  The locations are: Shop Rite Drugs, 426 1/2 - 432 15th Avenue East; Olive Terrace Apartments, 430 East Howell; the Pike Building, 1000 East Pike, and 1100 East Union. The artists will be identified through a community driven selection process.

Project Title: Gathering Buildings for Beacon Food Forest
Project Description: The Beacon Food Forest project will implement a community-wide process to build and install a gathering space pavilion tool shed, and watering system in the Spring and Summer of 2013. The outcome will be the first stage of an edible urban forest garden that will improve public health, reduce climate impact and improve food security.

The Alley Corridor Project will mobilize the Pioneer Square community to create great people places and transform its alleys into economic opportunities while preserving history.  The project will create an alley prototype with a shovel ready paving and lighting design that meets the needs of businesses and residents and improves safety, business opportunities, and walking spaces.

Project Title: Master Plan 1 P-Patch, and East Entrance
Project Description: The Phase I project will make improvements to the University Heights School including repair and restoration of siding and drainage; rebuilding of the P-Path site including handicap accessible plots and storage; enhancement of the East entrance with landscape beds, perimeter plants and trees.
Central Area Senior Center will oversee the planning and design of a new facility that houses expanded Senior and new Inter-generational programs.

Project Title: Dakota Street Right of Way Community Enhancement
Project Description: The project is a community-driven effort to replace an existing, vacant right-of-way with a beautifully landscaped place for the Delridge community to use and enjoy. This lot currently has an obscured entrance to the Longfellow Creek Trail system, and the proposed project would enhance the visibility and access to the creek and trails.

Project Title: Redevelopment of the Sacajawea Southern Playground
Project Description: The Sacajawea Elementary School PTA will implement the first phase of the redevelopment of the upper playground, comprising the restoration of the existing wetland and buffers, and the construction of the new playground and play structures.

Project Title: Redevelopment of the Sacajawea Southern Playground
Project Description: The Sacajawea Elementary School PTA will implement the first phase of the redevelopment of the upper playground, comprising of the restoration of the existing wetland and buffers, and the construction of the new playground and play structures.

Organization Name: Seattle Chinatown International District Preservation and Development Authority
Project Description: The Historic Alley Project will revitalize and reactivate Maynard and Canton Alleys in the Chinatown International District.  The project will be implemented through schematic design recommendations produced from a community engagement process that took place in 2012.

Friends of Lower Kinnear Park (FOLKPark)will complete Phase 2 of the North Trail Design Project with a Slope Stabilization Study. They will engage the community in events held in the park throughout the project. There will also be three interpretive signs designed for the park. The signs will require a Certificate of Approval from the Landmarks Board and approval from the Department of Parks and Recreation. FOLKpPark will report the number of new people who engage with a park event.

In cooperation with the Seattle Parks Department, and as an enhancement to improvements that will be made with Levy Funding, an approximately 65 X 80 foot sport court will be built next to the playground at Montlake Community Center.  Four to five pieces of adult fitness equipment will also be to the adjacent playground.

Phase 2 work on the View Ridge Play Space Project, will include design and installation of the play/sport courts and related amenities such as seating and natural elements and drainage improvements. This will markedly increase the availability of useable and safe play and gathering space in our community.

The Central Area Urban Garden is an agricultural demonstration project, designed to grow healthy, safe, affordable, organic vegetables indoors all year long. In addition to supplying abundant quality food, the project will provide training and education in food production - from seed to table - for youth in the community. The goal is to grow and distribute 5 tons of food including a wide variety of vegetables, herbs and house plants.

Outcomes:  Five tons of food will be grown and distributed; twenty students will recieve training in food production; the cost per unit of produce grown will be established; the exercise of growing their own food will positively impact the  food choices the students make.

Project Title: Get Lifted: an Elevator for Washington Hall
Project Description: Historic Seattle and its anchor partner tenants will raise awareness about accessibility issues at Washington Hall through the construction and installation of an elevator tower with an accessible elevator for this historic Central District landmark. An unveiling of the elevator along with tours of Washington Hall free and open to the public will be planned for sometime in July 2015. The tenants will monitor and document building visitors who need and use the elevator.

Phase II of this effort will provide the Freeway Estates Community Orchard with water service, a path, a shed, and garden areas. These improvements will encourage neighborhood involvement on a more consistent basis. 

Outcomes:
1.  Increased community participation in stewardship of the site
2.  Improvd access to water will allow for more trees and plants to be grow on site.
3.  New path will increase mobility for all users.

Project Title: Columbia City Gateway-Connecting People and Places
Organization Name: Friends of the Columbia City Gateway
Project Description: The Friends of the Columbia City Gateway will mobilize the community in transforming the unsightly and neglected NE corner of the Columbia School property into a signature streetscape and a welcoming `gateway` to the Columbia City neighborhood.

ECS will renovate and update their roughly 900 sq ft commercial kitchen and bring it fully up to code.  Our project aims to create a vibrant hub of community building, healthy eating, learning, celebration, and sharing.
Pathfinder K-8 PTSA will partner with the neighborhood to build the best possible playground for our community at the Pathfinder K-8 School.

Project Title: Remodeling and Updating the TCA Center
Project Description: The TCA will hire an Architect and General Contractor to remodel and update the entire building including the kitchen, bathrooms, windows, siding, roof and stairs. The plumbing and electrical systems will also be upgraded to keep the building in compliance with health and safety codes.

Friends of Yesler Swamp will construct an additional 200 feet of the Yesler Swamp boardwalk and complete the restoration of Yesler Swamp. The raised boardwalk will be part of a permanent, ADA accessible trail through this unique natural area.

The Eritrean Association of Greater Seattle will upgrade the kitchen space at the Eritrean Association Community Center (1954 South Massachusetts St) to a commercial-grade kitchen, making it possible to provide a significantly-increased number of food and nutrition-related activities and classes for the community. The project will also create an outdoor gathering space at the Community Center for cultural celebrations and events open to a wide variety of ethnic and community groups.

MÁS – Movimiento Afrolatino Seattle with the support of local Afro-Latino artists will produce a fall season of Afrolatino arts education events in fall 2015. These events have been designed after a year-long planning stage (2013) in which the community itself identified the need for programs centered around Afro Latino arts, culture and spiritual practices as tools to empower, eradicate racism and to increase the visibility and contributions of Afro Latinos.

Working with community members, The Alliance for Pioneer Square will plan and design improvements the neighborhood's parks and gateways, making them safe and welcoming for people of all walks of life.

Project Orca Playground (POP) plans to install playground renovations at Orca K-8 School. The renovated playground will provide walking paths, a re-surfaced field, and updated play areas for the community. Also, the redesigned lower entry will be more welcoming to the surrounding neighborhood as well as the school community.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Restoration of the Lewis Park natural Area will include ongoing community volunteer work in the accessible areas supported by hiring professional crews to work in the slope areas and an arborist provided by the Parks Department. Revisioning Test #2.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Whittier Elementary School Reader Board and Community Development
Project Description: Neighborhood Matching Funds will be used to hire a contractor to fabricate and install a reader board at Whittier Elementary School.  The reader board will be used to facilitate community and school messaging.  The project will also engage the neighborhood, residents, Whittier PTA, and Whittier Elementary staff and students in a community building work party to clean and beautify the grounds in and around the school.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Organization Name: Paradise-ing the Parking Lot Ad Hoc Coordination Team
Project Description: Award dollars will be used to hire a consultant to assess the feasibility of constructing a rain garden at 325 N 125th Street to alleviate on site flooding.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Development of a Site Plan that will specify recreational, ecological, and educational enhancements on B.F. Day school grounds. Group will go through a competitive process to hire a consultant to facilitate a community design process including three public meetings.  The process will create a Site Plan generated by parents, staff, students and neighbors.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: John Rogers Elementary School Emergency Preparedness
Project Description: John Rogers PTA will partner with teachers, faculty, parents, neighbors and emergency professionals to create a comprehensive emergency preparedness plan and supplies for use within the school in the event of a major disaster.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: East African Community Youth Sports and Mentoring Project Launch Day
Organization Name: Center for East African Community Affairs (CEACA)
Project Description: This one-day Launch Event is planned for September 10th, from noon to 6:00 PM, at Rainier Beach High School (8815 Seward Park Ave S). It will include: a community barbecue for nearly 100 families; a demonstration soccer game for two teams of 17 youths each; information by engaging speakers to promote healthy lifestyles, violence prevention and mentoring relationships; and recruitment of 17 adult mentors for 34 youths who will participate in sports teams and complete a total of four community service projects in a one-year period. The outreach focus will be on East African youth.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: This project will bring together Chinese Seattlites and jump-start the establishment of a local Chinese American Historical Society to document, preserve, promote and communicate about and for that ethnic group. Project includes community outreach, producing a timeline of local Chinese American experience, creating a website and a photo exhibit.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: This project will improve the existing Dakota Park playspace to better serve the larger south Seattle community and the New Rainier Vista neighborhood.  A new and enticing play area will be created that is safer, more dynamic and ADA accessible.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Senior Community Empowering Multi-Service Assessment Plan
Project Description: The primary goal of the ‘Senior Community Empowering Multi-Service Assessment Plan’ is to hire a design consultant that will lead the community through a commmunity engagement process to identify the desired ammenities for a community gathering space for seniors and their families in South East Seattle. A final report detailing the priorities and desires of the community will be produced. The center will be open to all residents but will focus on the needs of East African and other refugee families.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: This project will pull together community and local neighborhood residents (both existing and new) to participate in a number of charrette or programming sessions, preparing initial design and schematics for the kitchen expansion and 2nd floor addition, and preparing a fund raising plan.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Colman Park P-Patch Shed Improvement Project
Project Description: P-Patchers and neighbors will create usable and safe access to the tool storage shed for gardeners in the Colman Park P-Patch and all of the city p-patches who use the tools library stored in the shed. An education station will be created to help the neighborhood and community learn about organic gardening, composting, and how to develop a community perennial herb garden  The successful completion of this project will result in increased food bank donations from the community gardeners.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: [park] SPACE Design Development Plan and Construction Documents
Organization Name: Friends of Federal and Republican Open Space
Project Description: The consultant will continue the community engagement process around design development for the park site at Federal Ave E & E Republican.  This phase includes public meetings, Parks review of final design development and technical drawings to ensure conformance with Park Department standards.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Next Steps on the Path to Magnolia Manor Park
Project Description: Friends of Magnolia Manor will use the Small and Simple Projects Fund award to hire a consultant to continue with design development for Magnolia Manor Park and build upon the schematic plan that was created in the first phase of the project.  The Friends will continue to engage the public in building awareness, support and inviting participation by hosting a number of events and a public meeting.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Friends of Salmon Bay Playground will work with consultant on design development and construction documents for Salmon Bay School Playground.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Funding will be used to build a community garden to be located in a sunny area roughly 14 by 60 feet on the southwest front entrance of Greenwood Elementary School (GES).  The Greenwood School Garden (GSG or the Garden) will be an outdoor classroom and community gathering space nestled in the midst of the garden beds.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: 21st Century Leaders in Action: Bringing at-risk Somali youth closer to their families.
Project Description: This project will more closely conntect at-risk Somali youth to their elders and their community by engaging them as leaders. The youth will help organize and implement a series of intergenerational workshops on topics such as drug awareness, technology, navigating the school system, racism and cultural awareness.  A video documentary of this project will be created and shared with the community. The goal of this project is to strengthen and engage Somali families as they build community with their neighbors.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: John Rogers Elementary School Emergency Preparedness
Project Description: John Rogers PTA will partner with teachers, faculty, parents, neighbors and emergency professionals to create a comprehensive emergency preparedness plan and supplies for use within the school in the event of a major disaster.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Laurelhurst Elementary School Community Playground Renovation Project
Organization Name: Laurelhurst Elementary School Community Playground Renovation Project
Project Description: The project will renovate and redevelop the Laurelhurst Elementary School's North Playground, the second phase of a larger community project that began in 2007 with the renovation of the school's South playground. The funds will be used to install an ADA compliant play structure.  The community dollars will be used for a new asphalt surface.  These improvements will enhace the site and increase it's use as a neighborhood gathering space.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: The School-to-Pool Project:  McClure's Community Connection
Project Description: Project will create enhancements to the east side of McClure Middle School including pavers, landscaping and benches for seating to improve the appearance, cleanliness and maintability of the site.  The project will connect the school to the community by improving the overall aesthetic of the building and surrounding grounds.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Introduction To Rowing through the South Park Community Center.
Organization Name: South Park Community Center Rowing Club
Project Description: Purchase ergometers (rowing machines) for the purpose of conducting an excercise class geared toward the sport of rowing and aimed mainly toward teens in South Park. Offer classes to teach proper rowing techniques as well as a history, rules and culture of rowing.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Oxbow Park P-Patch and Gateway Project
Project Description: P-patch upgrades include: repair and relocation of tool shed, creation of a formal gateway, repair of damaged fencing, addition of three to four new garden beds, removal of invasive and dead plant material and the creation of a functional worm bin.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Organization Name: Youth Employment Skateboarding (YES) & Skate Like A Girl
Project Description: YES is a pilot youth employment and civic engagement program, training young adults ages 16 - 23 to work with youth in their community to plan and implement community-building programs for the Lower Woodland skate park. Specifically providing youth with structured and supervised skateboarding programs that allows youth to be engaged, have a voice, showcase their talents, develop leadership skills and be connected to the City.

Project Title: Roof replacements: Interbay P-Patch storage sheds
Project Description: The Interbay P- Patch community will work with their neighbors to replace the roofing on the tool and food bank structures.  These enhancements will give the garden an aesthetically consistent and secure look from the street.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Picardo P-Patch South Hillside and Garden Improvements
Project Description: Community members will develop, improve, and integrate the south half of Picardo P-Patch with the south hillside to provide more community garden space. Specific elements include: A community design process, increased gardening spaces, installation of edible and wildlife-attracting plants, incorporation of public gardening spaces like a children’s garden, a mushroom garden, bamboo cutting garden, and raised bed food bank gardening.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Rainier Beach Merchants Association (RBMA) will sponsor a public art walk in the Rainier Beach business district, highlighting the 10+ public artworks featured on both public and private property. The project is both a single-day event on Saturday, September 17, featuring docent-lead walking tours of the public artworks plus other art activities and entertainment, and year-long opportunity to take a self-guided tour of the permanent public artworks located throughout Rainier Beach.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Beacon Hill Carnival at ROCKiT Space
Project Description:
The 1st Annual Beacon Hill Carnival will bring together Beacon Hill business owners, residents, students and visitors for a fun, safe, creative good time. The Carnival is scheduled for Saturday, October 8, 2011 at the Beacon Hill Garden House.

The `Have a Seat, Beacon` project will produce 40 art chairs for shared use by neighborhood groups holding events at Lander Festival Street and other venues throughout the neighborhood. Design and decoration will be done by volunteers in the community. They will be both a tangible community asset and an ongoing reminder of the creativity in our neighborhood.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Sacajawea Park and South Playground Master Plan
Project Description: A design consult will lead a community engagement process to develop a plan for the redevelopment of the south playground of Sacajawea Elementary School, including a possible entryway and minimal passive elements in Sacajawea park. The goal is to create an integrated community gathering and recreation space for the benefit of the neighborhood, school and broader community.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: SLFF Free Screenings at the University of Washington
Project Description: With help from the Seattle Latino Film Festival, Friends of Latino Film will present four free film screenings on the University of Washington campus, with a talk-back and reception to follow. These four film presentations will be from Latino film directors highlighting the unique and moving aspects about Latino culture.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Community Tool Mobile will serve numerous West Seattle residents, projects, communities, and neighborhood groups by offering users an extremely accessible and free opportunity to participate in community sharing and creative collaboration through the utilization of a single, quality source of valuable tools.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: TFVS is a non-profit corporation established to open a dialogue between parents and youth to solve problems not through confrontation but through communication, understanding and tolerance. The project includes funding to support meetings for Somali elders that include discussion, lunch, and computer and ESL classes.  The project also includes computer and ESL classes for Somali families and individuals in the Lake City area.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Organization Name: Walking on Logs Landscape Restoration Group
Project Description: Enhance landscaping immediately surrounding the Walking on Logs statues with native and low maintenance plants suitable to the challenging conditions at the site in order to enhance the curb appeal of the site to the community, and to lessen maintenance needs.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Wedgwood Elementary Children And Neighbors Safety Project (WE CAN Safety Project)
Project Description: The Wedgwood Elementary Children and Neighbors Safety Project, or the WE CAN Safety Project is an initiative aimed at improving the safety of children and parents as they come and go from school each day, as well as other members of the community who use this area as a major pedestrian route in Wedgwood.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The White Center Community Summit is a community celebration that also acts as a “call to action” for the diverse people and organizations of White Center. The Summit brings together people from all backgrounds to organize around various critical neighborhood issues like health, housing, employment and education.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Broadview Emergency Preparedness and Comm. Hubs
Project Description: The Broadview Emergency Preparedness Group will help local residents prepare for disaster at the household and block levels, equip and maintain two emergency communication hub sites in Broadview; and train 20 neighbors and volunteers in CPR/AED & First Aid and in advanced emergency preparedness.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Monica's Village Place I Disaster Plan
Project Description: This community driven effort is a three part approach to disaster preparedness.  It includes building supplies, emergency kits and disaster training for 101 resients, first aid or CPR training for core volunteers and staff, and the creation of a disaster preparedness plan for families at Monica's Village Place I and the surrounding community.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: 3rd phase of trail project at greenspace.
Project Description: The third phase of Cheasty Greenspace at Mountain View will include a trail design and building project in the 10-acre forested park. This phase will include wayfinding signs, a guardrail to prevent trash dumping at one of the trailheads; and the addition of native plants. The NMF will pay for gravel, native plants, signage, signs, hardscaping materials, printing, translation, mailing, SDOT Guardrails and fiscal sponsor fee.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Garlough Avenue block watch group will organize their block for emergency preparedness as a group and create a tool for ongoing communication about emergencies and block watch issues.  This will include disaster preparedness training and purchase of emergency supplies for 20 - 25 households.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: IDIC IMMIGRANT & ELDERLY EMERGENCY PREP PROJECT
Project Description: The International Drop In Center's (IDIC) project will develop, implement, and document a model Emergency Preparedness Plan for 6 multilingual, immigrant elderly groups in SE Seattle. The project will update the IDIC Emergency Plan, distribute 120 disaster kits and provide emergency preparedness training to participants in their native language. The project will also implement a destailed outreach plan to engage diverse members of the community and residents.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Neighbors in the area of 41st Avenue SW/SW Portland Street/California Avenue SW will organize to provide training and emergency kits for 25 - 30 households.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description:
Funding will be used to develop and share information and plans for an emergency preparedness program within the Sunrise Heights Neighborhood Association [SHNA].  This will be done in conjunction with the  SNAP (Seattle Neighbors Actively Prepare) program, and coordinated with the work of Be Prepared West Seattle.  This includes training for 100 participants, the purchase of supplies for a number of emergency storage caches and the organization of a community leaders network.
This funding also is intended to build a set of documents and presentations that can be shared  with other Seattle neighborhoods.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: First aid training will be provided for 90 local residents in order to better equip the neighborhood for an emergency. The scheduled trainings will begin in July 2012.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Jackson Place Community Council in partnership with the Pratt Fine Arts Center will  launch an effort to create  a series of murals along South Jackson Street. The murals will be painted by local youth and will celebrate the rich history of music in the Central District.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Wedgwood Hub-Building the Pyramid Under the Chalet
Project Description: This project will create an emergency communications HUB in Wedgwood, including purchase of equipment for the site and supplies and training for 200 households.  Additionally 20 SNAP (Seattle Neighborhoods Actively Prepare) groups will be organized in coordination with the Office for Emergency Management.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Organization Name: Pike Street Market Senior Center & Food Bank
Project Description: The Market Community Mural: Master Pieces project brings together people from all walks of life to produce an uplifting piece of public art that increases awareness of food security issues and the Downtown Food Bank,located in the historic and highly visible Pike Place Market.  The mural will be painted by approximately 100 volunteers representing the Market and downtown communities, reflecting the area’s diversity and its shared values.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Ashia Circle will use local quilting experts in a supported group mentoring format to teach the art of quilting to multiple generations. They will sponsor a one week quilting circle camp, July 23-27, in Southeast Seattle for 25- 30 girls with assistance from the Pacific NW African American Quilters organization. The project will conclude with a community event that will showcase the girls work.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: St. Luke’s Urban Garden (SLUG), an empty lot that has been transformed through the efforts of neighborhing apartment and condominum dwellers will be further enhanced.  Improvements include  a rockery, an ornamental garden, signage, and worm bin compost benches.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Rainier Beach Moving Forward project will communicate and educate with diverse Rainier Beach community residents about the Rainier Beach 2014 Neighborhood Plan Update process.  The NMF award will be used for outreach and engagement in established community events and other venues where residents gather.  They will create a RB Moving Forward catalogue and host a special Town Hall meeting in January 2013.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Organization Name: Ballard Homes for All Coalition / Vehicle Resident Safe Parking Pilot
Project Description: This project will build community between and among housed and unhoused residents of Ballard by engaging them in creating a coordinated network of dispersed, safe parking locations for people who live in their vehicles.  Funding will be used to hire a coordinator who will identify potential sites,conduct the outreach and community engagement process, and collect quantitative data that may be used to determine the cost benefit of the project. The total number of spots will not exceed 15, over a maximum of 5 sites.   This project will be closely coordinated with the Human Services Department.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Project organizers will research emergency resources in the city of Seattle, particularly those available to the Latino immigrant population.  Resource materials and emergency kits will be distributed at eight disaster preparedness workshops designed for up to 200 Spanish speaking people January thru May 2013 at the Casa Latina Day Worker Center and St. Mary's Church.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: This project proposes to increase community engagement, knowledge, & participation in neighborhood-based preparedness efforts. This will be accomplished through CPR/First Aid and emergency preparedness training for 200 people, a mapping community assets, and carrying out a broad community outreach strategy to engage businesses and residents.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Arbor Heights Emergency and Disaster Preparedness
Project Description: The community of Arbor Heights will come together to develop and implement a plan for emergency and disaster preparedness, including training, disaster kits, and supplies for 400 Arbor Heights Elementary School staff, students, and neighbors.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Emergency Preparation for our Immigrant Community
Project Description: The Emergency Preparation for our Community project will train and equip residents of south east Seattle to respond to emergency situations and natural disasters.  The project includes emergency kits and training for 100 families and community workshops to help residents prepare and implement a family/community disaster plan.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Greening of the Burke-Gilman Trail at Sand Point
Organization Name: Friends of Burke Gilman Sand Point
Project Description: This project will enhance a heavily-used 1.2 mile stretch of the Burke-Gilman Trail.  Improvements include park benches, native plants, an educational kiosk, and an historic plaque.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Belltown Business Association will sponsor the Belltown Self-Guided Walking Tour from July through October 2012 during Seattle Center’s 50th Anniversary Celebration. Patrons will have two options for the tour - they can use a self-guided tour brochure with 50 locations of historical significance or use a smart phone online application.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Alki Art Fair will produce and promote West Seattle’s premiere summer art showcase on Alki Beach that celebrates arts and music.  The goal is to advance art education and appreciation while encouraging community involvement and cultural diversity for the community’s benefit. The fair is scheduled for July 28-29, 2012

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: B.F. Day School Playground - Design Development
Project Description: A consultant firm will be hired to produce Design Development (DD) documents from a previously prepared Conceptual Site Plan (CSP) for the exterior grounds of B.F. Day Elementary School. The final documents will guide the implementation of phased volunteer-based improvement projects and establish the framework for development of Construction Documents for implementation.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Clean Greens Market Stand provides produce grown without chemicals to inner city residents to help them eat healthy at an affordable price. Currently, there are too few local markets that supply the types of vegetables relevent to African Americans and African immigrants. The project includes support for additional equipment, market staff, community outreach,  and advertizing the market.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: This project will improve the pedestrian and bicycle trail that connects Melrose Ave E. to Lakeview Blvd E. Through a series of community cleanups, work parties, public meetings and outreach events, we will build neighborhood consensus around landscape and design improvements that will enhance the trail's aesthetics, increase safety, and create a more vibrant and inviting public open space.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: City Fruit, former volunteers from the Community Harvest of South West Seattle, and the Community Orchard of West Seattle plan to revive the former West Seattle community fruit tree harvest.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Community Cinema Group along with the Fremont/Wallingford neighborhood is organizing, promoting and hosting an outdoor showing of the movie,Goonies, at Gasworks Park, located at 2101 N. Northlake Way on Saturday evening, August 19, 2012. to encourage maximum attendance a number of kid friendly activities are planned.  Each community organization will be encouraged to produce a short film that outlines the benefits of volunteerism and promotes the philanthropic side of the neighborhood. These will be shown prior to the main event.   This project is a platform to introduce community members to the many volunteer based organizations in the neighborhood.  The goal is for people to enjoy a family friendly evening and discover new ways to use their talents and abilities closer to home. Showtime is approximately 7:00 p.m.  Neighborhood Matching fund events are supported on a one time only basis and are free and open to the public.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: To select a landscape architect to prepare a landscape design and plant list for the Charlestown Hillclimb with drought-tolerant and native plants. As part of an SDOT pedestrian enhancement project, all design elements and plans must be reviewed and approved by SDOT.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: SE Woods Restoration, Neighborhood Use Enhancement
