Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Friends of Haller Lake P-Patch will implement physical improvements at the Haller Lake P-Patch located at 13035 1st Ave NE.  Neighbors and community members will work together to rebuild garden beds, level uneven pathways, reposition shared composting bins, and enhance physical accessibility within the garden.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Youth Art on MLK at Thurgood Marshall Elementary
Organization Name: Friends of Hit the Streets on MLK
Project Description: Friends of Hit the Streets on MLK (FHSMLK) will work with Coyote Central to develop an installation of youth art on the MLK  Jr. Way frontage of Thurgood Marshall Elementary 2401 South Irving St, in the summer of 2015. The purpose of the project is to bring together the diverse communities of the neighborhood and celebrate the legacy of Thurgood Marshall.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Organization Name: Hirabayashi Place Legacy of Justice Committee
Project Description: This is a planning and design project that will not only reassert the cultural identity of Nihonmachi (Seattle's historic Japantown). But it will also lay the groundwork for public art honoring civil rights hero, Gordon Hirabayashi. The public art will be integrated into Hirabayashi Place, a low income housing building under construction at 4th Ave S and S Main St.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Organization Name: Sand Point Arts and Cultural Exchange
Project Description: Sand Point Arts and Cultural Exchange (SPACE) will work with youth from Solid Ground to develop an installation of youth art on Building 18 at Magnuson Park. The purpose of this project is to bring together volunteers, teaching artist, SPACE and youth to transform the windows into art.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Improvement Designs for I-5 Colonnade Open Space
Project Description: The Eastlake Community Council will use a planning and design firm to produce proposals and cost estimates by the end of 2015 for possible improvement and/or expansion of the I-5 Colonnade Open Space (800-1800 blocks of the I-5 right of way between Eastlake Avenue and Lakeview Blvd), as well as better pedestrian and bicycle connections with the surrounding area. The planning/design exercise will include three community meetings and coordination with agencies such as WSDOT, SDOT, and DPR.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Friends of Southeast Seattle Tool Library proposes to begin operation of a community tool lending library in a garage at the Genesee Apartments (4425 Martin Luther King Way S) in Rainier Vista in early 2015.  Tools will be stocked, and shelving and shop structures for stationary tools will be built. Community outreach will be done.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Organization Name: Wing Luke Museum of the Asian Pacific American Experience
Project Description: The Wing Luke Museum of the Asian Pacific American Experience will launch a year-long series of free community programs to explore the legacy of the Immigration Act of 1965. The program series will support the new community-created exhibit entitled “Immigration Act of 1965 Then and Now”.  The event series will consist of workshops, tours, interactive art activities, panel discussions, and an exhibit reception to explore concepts of citizenship, immigration and identity.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Building Civically Engaged Communities of Color
Organization Name: Coalition of Immigrants, Refugees and Communities of Color (CIRCC)
Project Description: The Coalition of Immigrants, Refugees, and Communities of Color (CIRCC) will strengthen its coalition organizational membership with more diverse geographical and racial/ethnic representation. By having a series of workshops that will educate coalition members and the community at large on voter registration, community organizing and policy issues that effect communities of color.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Central Area Chamber of Commerce (CACC) will host its 5th Black Irish Heritage Community Celebration in March 2015 (date and time TBD) at the 2100 Building on 24th Avenue South. This community-building event will celebrate the recognition of African-American and Irish lineage that has historically been overlooked as part of the Central District. Event details will be provided to the NMF project manager and posted on the DON Neighborhood Events Calendar.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: A Taste of Home will organize a series of events to celebrate the completion of their documentary “A Taste of Home”.  The events will take place in the International District.  These events will be designed to illustrate and further explore the documentary’s core themes, which highlight the importance of Seattle Chinatown’s immigrant history and its Chinese American culinary heritage.  The project will culminate with a screening event, including panel discussion and interactive activities.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Memory Lane: A Seniors Digital Story 1920-WWII
Project Description: The Central Area Senior Center will create an oral history documentary to capture the stories of seniors who grew up in Seattle between 1920 and World War II. The themes of community in the Central Area will be explored within the context of the roaring twenties, prohibition, Great Depression, New Deal, and World War II. The stories will be preserved on DVD and in print for public distribution.  The documentary will be screened at the Central Library, CASC, and at senior centers in Seattle.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Umoja Peace Center will organize, convene, and facilitate an inclusive community engagement process with African American residents, African American businesses owners, and other key stakeholders in the Central District. The process will include twelve public meetings. The community’s input will be gathered to create an action plan for improving the economic status of African Americans and preserving African Americans’ cultural identity in the Central District.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Community Self Defense and Wellness Program
Project Description: Bayan Pacific Northwest will plan and implement a series of self-defense classes designed for LGBTQ people and survivors of gender-based violence.  The series will focus on empowerment, self determination, communication, and promoting respect. There will also be a physical component of building confidence through conditioning and practicing self-defense skills.  The ten week series will be offered three times in one year.  The location will be in Seattle and is to be determined.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Develop 30% construction drawings for a new pocket park in the Olympic Hills neighborhood of Lake City.  NMF awarded funding in 2013-14 for work parties and to develop a concept plan that actively gathered neighborhood input. 30% construction drawings will advance the project and initiate the permitting process.

Project Title: Madison Park Emergency Hub Box and Supplies
Project Description: A Knaack box, designed to store emergency supplies will be purchased and installed on a concrete pad north of the Madison Park tennis courts.  This project supports the ongoing efforts of the Madison Park community to prepare for and respond to emergency situations.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Weedin Place Gateway Project is a collaborative project between the Roosevelt Neighborhood, SDOT, OED, and OAC. The project will convert a dangerous cut-through street into a safe public space. This gateway from Greenlake will be a pedestrian and bike friendly zone that bridges the gap between the 1-5 Park and Ride and the Sound Transit Light Rail station in the center of the Roosevelt commercial district.

Organization Name: Oromo Community Organziation of Seattle and King County Area
Project Description: Create voting awareness among East African communities by explaining its history and  benefits. We plan to encourage people to engage in issues, policies, services that affect their lives by exercising the right to vote. Our voters awareness will be implemented at East African events and places where they gather outside the home.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Organization Name: Clean and Safe Committee of the U-District  Partnership (UDP)
Project Description: The U-District has a busy pedestrian area, on or near University Way NE. Not all businesses provide rest rooms for non-customers. The U-District is in need of one or more public restrooms to serve the community. This project will provide the opportunity for public engagement on the process and the creation of a design plan.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Art on Pier 86 Grain Elevator & Silos
Project Description: Friends of Art on Pier 86 (FAP86) will hire a consultant to conduct a feasibility study of potential public art on Pier 86 structures. The study will examine design parameters, surface media, thematic ideas, and cost and maintenance considerations. Three public meetings will be held.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Queen Anne Neighborhood Alliance - in partnership with the QA Community Center, the QA Chamber, QA Helpline, local businesses and community organizations, and many QA residents - will host the neighborhood’s annual community celebration, Queen Anne Days, on Saturday, July 11, 2015 from 11:00am to 8:00pm, and Sunday, July 12, 2015 from 11:00am to 4:00pm, at Big Howe Park. The event is free and open to the public.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: This project located 52nd St S. and Mapes Creek Walkway will provide a movable pop-up park with giant chess pieces and roll up board to activate a Rainier Beach hot spot with positive, healthy play for adults and children. This event will coincide with the Bridge to Beach Clean up event on April 25, 2015.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Broadview Community Playground Improvement Project - Phase II
Project Description: The Broadview-Thomson PTSA will complete construction and permitting documents for renovation of the play areas adjacent to the Broadview Thomson K-8 school (13052 Greenwood Ave N.) and the Bitter Lake Community Center. Two community meetings will be held to provide updates.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Citizenship Festival Steering Committee  will organize a free multi-cultural citizenship festival on June 14, 2015 at Seattle City Hall located at 600 4th Ave. The festival will focus on promoting citizenship and civic engagement. It will feature a naturalization ceremony, an oath-taking for current citizens, a resource fair, speakers, and art.  There will be an accompanying public radio series to explore and discuss the themes of citizenship and civic engagement.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Public Space Activation Plan for First Hill
Project Description: The First Hill community will leverage the work and resources of the Public Realm Action Plan, by hiring a consultant to create a series of safe, active open spaces in the neighborhood.  The goal is to increase public safety, neighborhood wellness, connectivity, and community building through public space activation and a series of events that are scheduled during the summer of 2015.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Welcome to Our Native Land Powwow&Coastal Cultures
Organization Name: World Kulturz dba Native Kulturz Group
Project Description: Native Kulturz/Welcome to Our Native Land! (WONL) will organize three events to strengthen Native community presence and engagement in Seattle. The first is a Powwow and Coastal cultures celebration at Seattle Center on Saturday and Sunday, May 24-25, 2015, 11:00am - 7:00pm. Second, WONL will participate in the Seafair parade on July 25, 7:30pm. Third, youth leadership workshops will be held at Seattle Center and the Duwamish Longhouse in the fall of 2015. Events are free and open to the public.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Beacon Junction Mural Outreach and Design
Project Description: Beacon Arts will lead a community design process to create one or more murals for installation within public view on Beacon Hill.  One mural will be located at Dragon Auto Repair located at 2901 17th Avenue S.  Additional mural locations may be added depending upon community interest and property owner permission.  The mural designs will be developed based upon input gathered at public events on Beacon Hill. A public dedication will be held to celebrate the installation of the mural.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Homesight will organize the production and installation of eighty decorative banners on Martin Luther King Junior Way S between S Othello and S Graham Streets.  The utility pole banners will incorporate the word `Hello` in at least forty languages.  In addition to the banners, four clean-up events and a community celebration will further unite this business district, celebrate the community's multi-cultural identity, and welcome visitors from near and far.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Cal Anderson Park Alliance will activate Cal Anderson Park and engage the surrounding community through a series of four public events held in the spring, summer, and winter of 2015.  The events will be held at the park located at 1635 11th Ave.  They will help enhance feelings of safety and comfort in the park.  All events will be free and open to the public.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Green Lake Community Kids Fishing Event
Project Description: On May 2, 2015 from 9am to 2pm the Greenlake Chamber of Commerce is sponsoring the Fishing Kids Event at the West Casting Pier 7201 E Greenlake Dr. N. at Green Lake Park. The event is designed to provide children ages 5-14 years of age the opportunity to enjoy a quality outdoor recreational experience through the sport of fishing. Participants will also take part in water safety, boating and natural resources demonstration.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Families of Color Seattle Community Forums
Project Description: The Families of Color Seattle will organize a series of five free community forums during the summer of 2015. These forums will raise awareness about multi-cultural family planning, raising multi-cultural and multi-racial children, adopting children of color, anti-bias education, and about people returning to the workforce after becoming parents. Each forum will be led by expert panelists and will include a community panel discussion.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: This project would realign the plots at the Ballard P-Patch located at 8527 25th Ave NW to ensure equitable square footage for each gardener. The realignment, gives the opportunity to increase the garden’s accessibility by installing a system of wide hard-scaped paths. Other site improvements include adding an additional water spigot at the NW corner of the garden, moving ecology blocks to terrace the southwest corner and an underground conduit to provide power to the centrally located patio.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Building Strong Families from the Inside Out
Project Description: The project aims to improve family health and community through the development of a monthly community kitchen, a youth-oriented healthy eating and fitness challenge, local food initiatives and a PCC Tastemobile event.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Fitness is Fun June 22nd-June 24th Judkins Park
Project Description: A free three day health and fitness clinic for boys and girls ages 6 to 14 will take place June 22nd to June 24th from 9am to 12pm at Judkins Park, 2150 South Norman Street. Each day youth will focus on stretching, running and football fundamentals, while learning about the link between health and nutrition. Experts in the field inform the youth about healthy living and wellness and provide pre and post clinic assessments. Matching Fund supported events are funded on a one time only basis.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Organization Name: North End Health & Human Service Providers Co-op
Project Description: The North End Health & Human Service Providers Co-op will organize “Lake City Summer of Fun” to create a great summer experience for Northeast Seattle/Lake City youth and teens. Youth interns will  plan projects and activities for youth and families, especially low-income ones, at the Lake City Library and the North Seattle Family Resource Center. Community events will include an End of Summer BBQ at Virgil Flame Park on Friday, August 21,1:00-3:00pm. Events will be free and open to the public.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: Aktionsart will organize Black Box 2.0, a festival to showcase art that explores cinema through technology. It will run from May 6 to June 7, 2015.  Festival events will be held at various venues including Seattle Art Museum, Northwest Film Forum, and Velocity Dance Center.  Additionally, one or more temporary locations will be installed for presenting new media works. With multiple platforms and free admission, Black Box 2.0 will provide the public opportunities to experience art.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Title: Jackson Street Workers’ Mural Steering Committee
Organization Name: Friends of Jackson Street Mural Project
Project Description: This project enables engagement of community members in the design phase of a mural adorning the WA State Labor Council building at 16th & Jackson. The mural will depict significant, historical labor events in the rich multicultural context of the International and Central Districts. The mural will be visible along Jackson street.

Program Area: NMF Small and Simple Projects Fund
Project Description: The Capitol Hill Chamber along with area businesses, community organizations and volunteer would like to address the rapid changes that is happening on Capitol Hill. The Capitol Hill Leadership Development Project will work towards developing a broad based leadership organization that reflects the diversity of the community with the creation of a Business Improvement Area (BIA) to directly serve the Capitol Hill businesses, residents, nonprofits, & arts organizations.

Project Title: Night Out 2oth Avenue between E. Union & E. Marion Streets
Organization Name: Central Neighborhood Association, Central District Association
Project Description: Community group will host a Night Out Block Party on 20th Avenue between E Union and E Marion streets on Tuesday, August 2, 2011. In addition, the Central Neighborhood Association will update the Disaster Preparedness plan.

We the People Power is designed to be a collaborative, replicable, and scalable festival that will inspire and invite civic engagement.  On Saturday, June 16, 2012, directly following the Fremont Solstice Parade, We the People Power will illuminate Gasworks Park with art, creative and playful activities; meaningful discourse and opportunity.    

Get inspired and get involved!

Project Title: Art Walk Consortium: SeattleArtWalks.org Print Informational Cards for city-wide distribution
Project Description:
The Art Walk Consortium is a collaboration of neighborhood art walk organizers in Seattle, representing 13 neighborhoods with existing and ongoing monthly art walks. The goals of the AWC are to promote neighborhood art walks to the city’s residents, workers, and visitors; to ensure continued opportunities for early artists to show their work; to strengthen an individual’s ties to their community; and to grow the base of Seattle’s art supporters. 
The AWC is requesting funds to produce a set of initial marketing materials (rack cards) about SeattleArtWalks.org. These will be used to promote the rich and diverse hyperlocal neighborhood business districts in the City of Seattle which host monthly art walks by directing them to a single online source for information about where and when neighborhood art walks occur and how to participate.
First ever Gay Pride Picnic in South Park with food, music, entertainment and art. The picnic is scheduled for Sunday, June 19th, at Duwamish Waterway Park from 1:00-5:00 PM.

Friends of The Alley proposes a Small Sparks grant to create a photography display in Pioneer Square’s Nord Alley. The display will be unveiled during a Nord Alley Party during the First Thursday Art Walk on July 7, a gathering that promises to draw hundreds of people into the alley for music and conversation.

Project Title: West Seattle Blockwatch Captains' Appreciation Celebration
Project Description: We are hosting a West Seattle Blockwatch Apprecation Celebration to recognize blockwatch groups and captains for all their work throughout the year. Captains play an important role in recruiting more community members into the leadership role for their neighborhoods. This community event is scheduled for September 23, 2011 at the West Seattle Precinct.

Organization Name: Central Neighborhood Association, Central District Association
Project Description: Host a Nation Night Out Block Celebration on August 2, 2011 in the Central District (on 17th Ave between Columbia & Marion Streets). Our community celelbration will include entertainment, potluck and exchange of community gardening materials.

A family friendly community event is planned for August 6th, 2011 from 10am to 5pm at  Hunter Farms, located at 7734 - 35th Avenue NE. The Planet Home Sustainable Living Festival will offer hands on activities and demonstrations on topics such as permaculture, emergency preparedness, home diy maintenance, waste reduction, and alternative energy. There will be a survey instrument on site for participants to assess their skills and expertise in sustainable practices as well as learn about resources and training opportunities. There will also be live music and activities for kids.

Project Title: 54th Ave SW between Andover & Dakota Night Out Block Party
Project Description: Neighbors will host a National Night Out Block Party on Tuesday, August 2, 2011. The event will focus on 54th Ave SW between Andover and Dakota Streets.

Project Title: Highland Park's Night Out Block Party
Project Description: On August 2, 2011 neighbors on 12th Avenue Southwest between Kenyon and Elmgrove streets will host a National Night Out Block Party. This community celebration will include a potluck, barbeque and children's activities. This family friendly event will bring our neighborhood together.

Project Title: 8100 Block of 7th Ave SW Night Out Celebration
Project Description: Neighborhood organizers will organize a National Night Out Against Crime Celebration for the 7900, 8100, and 8200 blocks of 7th Avenue SW on August 2, 2011. The goal is to bring our neighbors together in a relaxed social atmosphere and to foster their individual interests in building community through discussion, sharing contact information, and introducing themselves to the neighborhood. In additon, 3 emergency preparedness kits will be raffled at the event.

Project Title: Rainier Visita Night Out Against Crime
Organization Name: New Rainier Vista Traffic and Safety Committee
Project Description: Community members will host a Night Out Against Crime event on Saturday, July 30 2011 in the Rainier Vista Central Park. This community event will have a multicultural focus with cultral performances, community potluck, information tables and partnerships with community-based organizations (Neighborhood House, REWA, Seattle Housing Authority, and the Boys and Girls Club).

Project Title: Rainier Beach Night Out Against Crime 2011 Celebration of Historic Drug Abatement
Project Description:
This neighborhood mobilized to work with the City Attorney and Police to get the first successful Drug Abatement in the City of Seattle in 11-years.   This event will celebrate that accomplishment and provide an opportunity for affirmative outreach to low-income and households of color, under-represented in the block watch.

The event will be held on the public street of the 8400 Block of 55th Ave. S. using a street closure permit obtained for Night Out Against Crime.

Project Title: South Park Night Out Against Crime Community BBQ & Event
Project Description: South Park community members will participate in the 27th annual National Night Out (NNO) which is a unique community crime/drug prevention event. This community gathering is scheduled for Tuesday, August 2nd, 2011 at the South Park community center. The purpose of the event is to heighten crime and drug prevention awareness, generate support for and participation in local anticrime programs; strengthen neighborhood spirit and police-community partnerships; and send a message to criminals letting them know that neighborhoods are organized and fighting back.

Project Title: North Delridge Educational and Information Forum Regarding Proposed Downtown Emergency Service Center (DESC) Facility located at 5434-5444 Delridge Ave SW
Project Description:
Through June-July 2011, there has been an overwhelming community interest in a proposal to create a supportive care facility “for men and women who are disabled and currently homeless.` The community meetings previously held have been in locations that do not accomodate the number of community members wanting to attend. 

The North Delridge Community Council will provide information and host a series of community forums for North Delridge residents to understand all of the complex details related to this proposed Downtown Emergency Service Center.

For years the Delridge P-Patch has been plagued by veggie theft because its location off a major road (Delridge Way SW) and its open layout (required for a P-Patches on City Park land).  This theft has caused numerous P-Patchers to stop gardening or consider stopping gardening at this P-Patch.   This fencing project will put fences around the P-Patches 4 quadrants while maintaining the P-Patches open layout.  Signage will also be incorporated to denote public area and P-Patcher only areas.  The goal is that this fencing will add a physical and psychological barrier in effort to reduce theft.  It will also improve the aesthetic of the P-Patch.

Prior to constructing the fence all gardeners at the Delridge P-Patch will be invited to a meeting to help design the fences.  After the design is agreed upon, we will set a construction date, and build the fence.

The Ferdinand P-Patch community and their neighbors are taking steps to conserve water and enhance the ammenities at the garden.  A hose bib will be purchased, leaks will be repaired and  gates will be designed and built.  A community celebration is planned once the improvements have been made.  The entire community will be able to learn more about water conservation and enjoy the the newly refreshed garden.

The Nickelsville Community in cooperation with their neighbors will develop a mobile flower garden and a community gathering spot. As a homeless community, Nickelsville must move several times a year and it can be a challenge to connect with their new neighbors.  Establishing a flower garden will demonstrate to their neighbors that they are committed to the maintenance and upkeep of the community.  Developing a ralaxing and inviting community gathering space within Nickelsville will strengthen their connections with their neighbors.  A community potluck will be held once the improvements have been made.

Project Title: Back to School Night Out Celebration
Project Description: On September 30, 2011, from 5 p.m. to 9 p.m., residents of South Shore Court, Villa Park, Henderson Arms, and surrounding Rainier Beach homes are invited to come together to strengthen neighborhood spirit, promote public safety, and connecting one another to resources available to the Rainier Beach community at the “Back to School Night Out Celebration.”

Project Title: P-Patch Harvest Banquet & World Dance Party
Project Description: P-Patch community gardeners and volunteers are organizing a Harvest Banquet and World Dance Party on Sunday, October 9, 2011 6:00-9:00pm at the Phinney Neighborhood Center. This event will help us build ties among community centers, neighborhood centers, P-Patch members, and local community agriculture groups. Our short-term goal is to celebrate our harvest and to build new alliances among different community groups. Our long-term goal is to encourage the growth of local food-growing and sustainable agriculture.

Project Title: Synergistic comm building outreach for emer prep
Project Description: Host an emergency preparedness workshop on Thursday, October 20, 2011 at the University Child Development School Auditorium. We will focus on educacting and connecting residents of our neighborhood (east of I5, west of 12th Ave NE, south of Ravenna, north of 45th Ave NE) to be prepared in the case of an emergency.  The workshop will include a training segment from the City of Seattle's emergency preparedness team, followed by a segment in which people can network with their neighbors to plan out neighborhood meeting locations and actions in case of an emergency.

Project Title: Building a Stronger and Prepared Rainier Beach
Organization Name: Rainier Beach Emergency Preparedness Organizing Committee
Project Description: To organize a Saturday morning, potluck event with neighbors, local churches, neighborhood association, and schools to learn about the basics of disaster planning and the steps to being organized. Office of Emergency Management has agreed to provide the presentation on Nov. 5th, 10am-noon at the Rainier Beach Methodist Church. Core group members from the Rainier Beach Emergency Preparedness Committee will facilitate a discussion to include sharing contact information, mapping, and future training and networking opportunities.

Neigbors and community garden participants will collaborate to clear and plant a berry patch.

Goals: teach benefits of perrenial food sources, specifically native berries; improve habitat for wildlife; create an attractive no-maintenance garden space.

Funds will be used to purchase plants/bulbs for the new community / shared garden beds in the planting strip at Republican P-Patch; purchase a new picnic table to use for evening / weekend garden potluck gatherings; and purchase a new push mower to maintain grassy area around new beds.

The Seattle Race Initiative seeks to teach people to have everyday and nonthreatening conversations about race.  To celebrate the 50th Anniversary of the Civil Rights Act, two community forms will be held, Friday December 9th from 6-9pm  and Saturday, December 10th from 8:30 am - 4:00 p.m. at Mt Zion Baptist Church, 1634 - 19th Avenue.  The Friday night session will focus on a look at race through the arts. The Saturday session will include small groups discussions with expert facilitators. 

Because conversations about race are viewed as taboo in American society, this weekend aims to make the conversation easy, non-threatening and fun so that people can begin to talk to each other and about race with less fear.  The goal of this event is to build stronger conections between neighbors and to recognize and appreciate cultural differences among Settle's diverse population.  

Neighborhood Matching Fund supported events are funded on a one time only basis and must be free to the public.

The Small Sparks Fund will be used to assist the Loyal Heights neighborhood prepare as a geographic emergency hub in Ballard primarily through networking with the Loyal Heights Community Center (LHCC) List Serve email and the LHCC advisory council.  An inventory of neighborhood assets will be developed.  Fliers, as well as PSAs, will also be used to advertise meetings.  An Icom radio and FCC license will be purchased to afford Loyal Heights compatibility with the Office of Emergency Management.

The purpose of this two day workshop scheduled February 18th and the 25th, 2012 from 11:00-2:00 at 2720 S Hanford St in Rainier Vallye, is to invite the  community together to particpate in learning how the recycling process of organic matter works and to learn how recycable matter is converted into new products.  There will be interactive games and learning activities for all ages.

A free family friendly Vietnamese Lunar New Year Celebration for the New Holly community will be held Friday, January 20, 2012, from 6-8 pm at the New Holly Gathering Hall, 7054 - 32nd Avenue South. The event will involve 300 community members and 50 volunteers in an evening of cultural activities, arts and crafts, food, and entertainment.  It is an opportunity to promote a greater understanding and appreciation for the Vietnamese culture. This project will develop leadership skills and  encourage civic engagement among Vietnamese youth.  Matching Fund events are supported on a one time only basis.

Our project is to create a new organization called the Alki Art Fair, which will be a non-profit group whose purpose is to plan, fund and produce the annual Alki Art Fair. This event is West Seattle’s premier summer art showcase on Alki Beach that celebrates visual arts and music. Our goal is to advance art education and appreciation while encouraging community involvement and cultural diversity for the community’s benefit.

Bitterlake Comunity Prepared's goal is to create  connections with partners in our community to be able to assist one another, in the event of an emergency or disaster.  Community workshops, and targeted invitations, to diverse parts of the neighborhood, will be held at the Bitterlake Community Center on April 7.   The day long Workshop will cover: 1.household preparedness;
2.personal preparedness for emergencies such as power outages,snow/wind storms,earthquakes,and fire; 3.  Broadview project trainings for volunteer strategically located neighborhood
community-Communications HUBS in the north.  
 The workshops will be interactive incorporating hypothetical scenarios,handouts and will include networking before, during, and after. Contact information will be gathered for a shared  professional resource list in case of emegency or disaster.

Project Title: International Womens Day 2012: Culture and Action
Project Description: We plan to celebrate International Women’s Day (IWD) with a cultural and activism event that will bring together a wide range of Seattle’s women's communities. Organizers from several women's groups and communities are planning the event, which will include performers, fashion, and food from many cultures, panels and workshops addressing critical issues affecting women in diverse communities, and a time to honor local grassroots activist women. We are making a special effort to involve members of immigrant communities, for whom IWD is an important celebration.

Parent Information Night - An evening of food and fellowship on June 8, 2012 at the Bailey Gatzert Elementary School to introduce parents to:
1. The Family Engagement Action Team (FEAT)
2. Class parent representation
3. School website features 
4. Stategies for how to increase communication between home and school
5. Various strategies for how to increase learning at home

On August 4, 2015 from 6pm to 10pm the Friends of 16th Ave will have a Night Out Seattle for neighbors to join together for a BBQ and fun on the 300 Block of 16th Avenue between E. Alder St and E Jefferson St.

Project Title: Neighbors Night out on 36th Ave W
Project Description: The neighbors on W Smith and 36th Ave W will have an informal gathering on Night Out, August 6, 2013 from 6:00-9:00pm.  We will encourage our new families to join us so that our gathering bring us together in the name of building community.

The Ballard P-Patch has a portion of their community garden set up to be an `Enabled Garden`. This space serves the needs of people who are physically or developmentally unable to tend a traditional garden. Enabled gardening allows more people to enjoy the benefits of working with plants. In addition, the Enabled Garden provides a garden space for visitors who have mobility issues to safely visit and enjoy the garden. The Ballard P-Patch community has identified that our Enabled Garden can be improved by resurfacing the ground by replacing the wood chips currently used with a water permeable hardscape. This will improve mobility greatly as the hardscape will provide a more stable surface reducing balance issues created by a springy surface created by the wood chips. This will also make it so that wheelchairs, walkers, crutches and canes will not sink into the ground when conditions are wet. We will also hardscape a pathway from the main entrance of the P-Patch to the patio, which is centrally located. This will make the patio area accessible.

Project Title: NW 61st is Getting Prepared from 9-11th Ave NW
Organization Name: NW 61st is Getting Prepared from 9-11th Ave NW
Project Description: This project builds on prior neighborhood organizing efforts to prepare for a disaster.  The group is a registered SNAP group, has a neighborhood newsletter, and is actively involved with training and drills.  Funds from the Small Sparks award will be used to purchase supplies and materials including communication via walkie talkies, First Aid EMT Trauma Bag, emergency blankets, tarps, fire extinguisher, and water purification tables.  Currently, 30 of 31 homes on the block are participating; 5 homes are very prepared and 25 homes are preparing. An outcome for the project is to have people from all 31 homes on the block prepared and able to take care of themselves and each other for several days following a disaster.

Organization Name: Seattle Alliance of Black School Educators (SABSE)
Project Description: The Seattle Alliance of Black School Educators in partnership with key community leaders is sponsoring a Parent Forum to be held on Saturday, March 17th at Rainier Beach High School, 8815 Seward Park Avenue South.  The time is from 9:30 a.m. until 3:00 p.m. There will be interactive workshops on a variety of topics designed to enhance and strengthen parent engagement in the education process.  This is event is free and open to the public.  Matching Fund events are supported on a one time only basis.
Build a rainwater catchment and storage structure for the Brandon Community Garden

Project Title: Bridge to Beach Clean Up of Othello Town Center
Project Description: On Aunday April 22, 2012 we will clean up all trash in the Othello Town Center.  We will remove all weeds from the planting strips along MLK Way between Othello and Myrtle.  We will plant and beautify the walk through area at the corner of Myrtle and 42nd St.

Project Title: Information Flyers for GL Emergency Preparedness
Project Description: Members of the block watch group will create flyers that list the community resources available for emergency preparedness including the information hubs in the Green Lake area.  The flyers will be distributed at community events and locations such as the Green Lake Library, senior facilities and neighborhood schools.

Our purpose is to promote a cleaner, safer and brighter neighborhood through a Bridge to Beach event on Sunday April 22, 2012. This event would focus on bringing residents and the business community together to conduct clean - up and talk about plans to continue to improve the physical surroundings of Rainier Beach with future events.

Friends of the Alley propose two installations that green Pioneer Square Alleys and invite community participation.

One installation, MOSS-by-number, uses moss to create a set of artistic portraits and paintings in the alley to entice people into the space and activate the alley.  The installation will be featured on the May 3rd First Thursday Pioneer Square Art Walk and stay in place for the following two months, allowing the moss to grow and morph the artwork and bring new pedestrians into the alley space. 

The MOSS-by-number installation deploys living, material to create half “mossed” portraits and landscapes to inspire playful notions of nature in the “city” as well as promote new ways of perceiving an urban alley. The artwork uses locally grown moss and wooden boards, playfully cut in the style of the 1950s “Paint By Numbers” phenomenon(see photo).  The boards will display a two dimensional artwork create with moss highlights that will continue to grown throughout the month they are in the alley. 

The second installation, Alley Pallets, transforms discarded industrial pallets into vertical gardens.  Residents and businesses along the Nord Alley and other Pioneer Square alleys will be organized to create green walls along their homes and buildings.  The discarded pallets are turned upright, have landscape fabric stapled to their backs and then are filled with soil and plants. (see link: http://lifeonthebalcony.com/how-to-turn-a-pallet-into-a-garden/)

Out There is a week long summer camp for lgbt youth and allies from all over Seattle. Our aim is affordability, fostering community, and teaching youth valuable life skills such as self esteem, public speaking, literacy skills. It will be offered to youth ages 14 to 20. Each day they will come into contact with local teachers and renowned poets alike to learn from. Finally, at the end of the camp there will be a performance open to the public also at Langston Hughes Performing Arts Center.

Project Title: South Park Neighborhood Center Open House
Organization Name: South Park Neighborhood Open House Planning Committee
Project Description: The first annual South Park Neighborhood Center Open House is scheduled for Saturday, June 9, between the hours of 2:00 - 6:00 pm. The event will showcase the variety of activities that occur in the facility and celebrate the community groups who call the building home.  There will be special activities for families during the first hour.  This community celebration is open to any one who lives, works or plays in South Park.  There will be food, exhibits and entertainment. The center is located at 8201 - 10th Avenue South in Seattle.  All Matching Fund events are free and open to the public and are supported on a one time only basis.

Lake City Community Council in partnership with the University of Washington School of Urban Planning is organizing and holding a large public workshop on Saturday, May 19, 2012 to work with both undergraduate and graduate students from the University of Washington as well as Planning Commissioners and planners from other cities to develop a vision for 14 Pierre properties in Lake City which the Pierre family wants to lease and redevelop with other uses than car dealerships. The public workshop will provide opportunities for mental mapping excercises, surveys, and charettes to help the local community give the Pierre family a vision for reuse of their properties in Lake City. All North District Neighborhood groups have been contacted, invited, and requested to share the date and event information.  Results of the workshop will be given to the Pierre family through Don Moody of CBRE Realty for their consideration, and follow up steps with the Pierre family will be outlined at the workshop.

Our Greenways Group wants to invite people from Wallingford on the afternoon of Saturday, June 16th, to celebrate the construction of Seattle's first Neighborhood Greenway along North 44th and 43rd, from Latona Avenue to Stone Way. These low-stress, non-arterial streets are designed to prioritize pedestrians and bicyclists, protect the most vulnerable users of our roadway including the elderly and children.

Project Title: Fiestas Patrias Edition of the Latino Cultural Magazine.
Project Description: To publish, promote and distribute 1,000 copies of the Latino Cultural Magazine to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Seattle Center along with Fiestas Patrias 2012. Our magazine offers artistic, cultural and events information to Latino community in Seattle.

The Leschi Business Association and the Leschi Community Council are collaborating to host an art walk along the sidewalks of Lakeside Avenue S. and Lake Wahsington Blvd. We are highlighting local artists and businesses in the Leschi neighborhood. We will also have entertainment and activities for children.

Project Title: Lake City-Neighbors United to be Prepared
Project Description: The group will Host a “Safety Saturday Festival” on Sat July 14, 2012 for the diverse population of residents and businesses on 33rd Avenue NE between 125th to 127th. The Festival will provide an interactive environment where residents can learn how to prepare and respond before, during, and after a disaster.

Project Title: Artists of color outreach and community-building
Project Description:
In celebration of its first year as a new arts resource in Chinatown-International District, International District Engaged in the Arts (IDEA) Odyssey artist collective will hold two neighborhood events in late June and early July. The free public events will include mini art-making workshops, local music, food, and a community-produced art project. 

The goals of these events are to increase visibility of the arts in the neighborhood, reach and share the collective's vision and benefits to emerging local artists, and bring together residents, youth, artists, and local business owners through art, music and food.

Webster Park was dedicated on June 1, 1997, the culmination of an 8 year community effort that also spawned Groundswell NW. On June 9, 2012 from 1-4 p.m., Friends of Webster Park is hosting a celebration of Webster's 15th anniversary along with the 20th Anniversary of Groundswell's incorporation.

The garden at Bryant Elementary school is referred to as the Hands on Garden and overseen by the schools/neighborhood gardening group Garden Buddies.  Our neighborhood garden currently has a mulched path that needs to be removed and replaced.  We will dig 6 in down in a 26 ft x 5 ft area (depth required to reach sandy garden floor), remove the mulch, fill the area with Quarter Minus (crushed rock used in landscaping projects), grade the area to an even level, lay 13 non-skid 24 in x 24 in stepping stones and fill back the area with the remaining crushed rock to anchor the paver stones. We plan to complete the project in one afternoon from approximately 9am-3pm.

Project Title: Mosaic Tile Mural for Hazel Heights P-Patch
Project Description: In order to create a more welcoming presence in the neighborhood, gardeners and local talent will design, fabricate, and install a 28 square foot custom  mural at the entrance to the Hazel Heights P-Patch. This project will further enhance the P-Patch as a community gathering space.

Youth and their parents in the Yesler Terrace community will be invited to a resource fair to learn about all of the free activities available in the neighborhood for youth this summer. The event is scheduled for Saturday, June 23rd from 10:00 am until 10:00 pm at the baseball field behind the Yesler Community Center which is located at 917 East Yesler Way. The resource fair will be open from 10am until noon and from 2pm until 4pm.  Lunch will be served at noon with a variety of kid friendly activities occuring throughout the day.  A film will be shown at dusk. This event will also provide an opportunity for parents to meet and connect with each other in a fun and engaging atmosphere.

Project Title: The Health and fitness clinic promotes health.
Project Description: The three-day health and fitness clinic promotes health, physical fitness, nutrition and skill development.  The free clinic will be held at Judkins Park on June 26, 27, and 28. Local professional athletes and community leaders will work with the youth, speaking about maintaining physical fitness, developing healthy eating habits and encouraging academic achievement.

The Georgetown Garden Walk on the second Sunday of July unites the business, residential and art communities of Georgetown in common purpose by attracting visitors to explore residences and business and discover the creative diversity of the historic Georgetown neighborhood. The Georgetown Merchants Association, United Artists of Georgetown and Georgetown Community Council collaborate on this ambitious community-building project.

Project Title: Crime, Preparedness and Organize Blocks of People
Project Description: Project will use a Night Out gathering on August 11 to help organize the 1800 block of 25th with Block Watch captains, safety procedures and begin talking about emergency preparedness for residents with at least 50 people attending.

A group of volunteers wish to organize a once a month neighborhood celebration at Cascade Peoples Center on the First Friday of every month through 2012. We will encourage a positive feeling through culture, art, food, education, crafters, and fun, fun, fun! Our motto is `a place where you can...`

Link to Lake is a 1.5 mile walking route starting at the Columbia City Link Light Rail Station and continuing through 5 city parks ending at Lake Washington.  The walking route, developed last year through neighborhood collaboration, builds community in Rainier Valley while encouraging physical activity, increasing knowledge of our community assets and improving public safety. The trail improvement project will involve neighbors as they:  
(1) Distribute color copies of the route map
(2) Install crossing flags and containers at 44th/South Genesee Street and 45th/Lake Washington Boulevard South
(3) Celebrate the improvements by planning and leading a community walk along the route at the Rainier Valley Summer Streets Party on Saturday, August 18.

The Resource Conservation Landscape Drip Irrigation Project will engage community members to install a simple drip irrigation system as part of this sustainable landscape project at Magnuson Community Center.  The volunteer-led drip irrigation installation event will add to the landscape project’s ability to demonstrate water conservation methods, build community, and provide public education to volunteers and to the community center’s year-round visitors.
Small Sparks funding supports the purchase of irrigation system components and supplies needed in order for the drip irrigation project to be installed at work parties on July 15 and in other work parties in July.

Project Title: Cherry Hill Community Association Night Out Event
Project Description: The Cherry Hill Community Association will host a Night Out event on Tuesday, August 7, 2012 at the Spring Mini-Park. Community outreach will be done in the area from 18th Ave to 12th Ave and E Union to E Cherry who we have not been able to reach in the past.  This will help increase community cohesiveness, meet new residents, renew contact with old members of CHCA, include children and older residents of our neighborhood and especially to outreach to the many renters in our area who may not feel connected to each other, the larger community or the neighborhood.

Organization Name: Friends of Little Saigon c/o SCIDPDA
Project Description: Celebrate Little Saigon is an annual night festival that celebrates Vietnamese culture and brings communities together. This event is hosted by Friends of Little Saigon, a grassroots non-profit organization dedicated to preserving the unique cultural fabric of Seattle’s Little Saigon while spurring neighborhood improvements and activities that all Seattleites can enjoy. The event will be held at the Asian Resource Center on Saturday August 18, 2012. Celebrate Little Saigon is a fun, family-oriented event that showcases the unique cultural flavors of the Vietnamese community. Kids and adults alike will enjoy an evening of delicious food, cultural performances, art, music, and a touching Vietnamese movie. Small Sparks funds will go towards supporting the movie screening of “The Owl and the Sparrow”, a film about the journey of a young girl and the relationships she builds along the way. As the headlining event, this film will help us draw families from the surrounding neighborhoods as well as from throughout the Greater Seattle Area.

The goal of this project is to assess the current needs of the Central District Community as it relates to government services, local businesses and social programs.  To accomplish this survey tables will be set up at the following locations and times.  Union Business Center, 1162 - 23rd Avenue, August 18 and 24 from 11 am - 3 pm, and Red Apple Promenade, 2301 South Jackson Street, September 1 and 8 from 11 am - 3 pm.  The informaton will be entered into the CD4EVER database and shared with all participants.  This is the first step in involving community members in advocating for neighborhood improvements, services, and programs.

Project Title: A Concert in International Children's Park
Project Description: The Autumn Moon Festival present great opportunity to celebrate community with the children of the International District/Chinatown. We propose to spark a community organizing campaign including residents and local businesses that will culminate in a concert for children in International Children's Park on Saturday, September 8, 2012.

Organization Name: World Kulturz dba Native Kulturz Group
Project Description:
This is a project to survey people living in the High Point neighborhood area of West Seattle.  The survey will ask residents what they would do to build, cultivate, develop and sustain relationships with their neighbors and area resources.  With emphasis on including community leaders in the survey development, distribution and dissemination, and analysis, key input and inclusion with a cultural emphasis will be stressed.  This is important considering many neighborhood individuals and families are of immigrant, low income, and diverse language backgrounds.

Volunteers will invited to join the team to assist with disseminating the survey, collecting results, and assisting with the final report presentation event located at the High Point Neighborhood House that is central to many people living in the area.  These volunteers will come from schools, community centers, neighborhood groups, and other area residents.

Using the data, the project steering committee members will compile survey results into a report.  Significant and major findings will be presented at a celebration event held at the High Point Neighborhood Center on Sylvan Way and Lanham Place.

The celebration event will involve a presentation by steering committee members, food, and cultural music and art will reflect the diversity of community participants.  It is projected that 300 people will be present at this program.

A community event will be held on September 15th from 12noon to 2pm at the South Park Community Center located at 8319 8th Ave. S. The goal is to enhance the South Park component of the weekend's Fiestas Patrias activities by providing a band and activities for children, like face-painting and mask-making. This will help keep Fiestas Patrias alive and vibrant in its original home for the neighbors who originally made the event a success and can not easily travel to Seattle Center for the other Fiestas Patrias events.

We're hosting an event on September 13, 2012 during the Lake City Farmers Market to reach out and engage community members. We want to share information on what is happening in the area and find out more about what they're interested in. We're focusing on a fun non-meeting-like atmosphere with food and games to bring people in.  We will also give market bucks to market shoppers who stop by to share their ideas with us.

Project Title: Rainier Beach Picnic Potluck Community Builder
Project Description: The Rainier Beach Community Club will be sponsoring a neighborhood picnic and potluck at  Beer Sheva Park, 8650 - 55th Avenue South on Wednesday, August 22, from 4:00 pm - 9:00 pm. There will be good music, great food, and activities for all ages. This family friendly event will be a great opportunity for folks to connect with their neighbors. The Rainier Beach Community Empowerment Coalition will be co-sponsoring the event with participation from the Filipino and Ethiopian communities. Along with the community building activities participants will receive instruction on proper recycling and composting techniques.

Organization Name: The Townships Garden P-patch at Broadway Hill Park
Project Description:
The Townships Garden P-Patch project will enhance the existing interim garden in Broadway Hill Park to provide inclusive opportunities for urban agriculture and to build community
by working together.

Southeast community members are sponsoring a back to school barbeque for students of all ages on Saturday, September 8th from 3:00-7:00 pm at  Genesee Park, located at 4316 S. Genesee. This is a free family oriented event that will provide an opportunity for students and parents to connect and plan for a productive school year. There will be food, a resource table, kid friendly activities and information on local PTA's and other school based organizations.

Project Title: ROUNDABOUT @ 9TH AVE NE & NE 47TH ST SEATTLE
Project Description: REDO, MULCH AND RE- PLANT PERENNIAL AND ANNUAL FLOWERS AND BUSHES AT THE ROUNDABOUT AFTER A CAR RAN OVER AND DEMOLISHED IT. WOULD LIKE TO REDO AS ALL OF THE NEIGHBORS WERE GRATEFUL FOR THE BEAUTY IT BROUGHT TO NEIGHBORHOOD. WE ARE PLANNING TO DO THE WORK ON OCTOBER 27 AND 28.

The purpose of Stayin’ Alive is to provide CPR training to the Ballard, Magnolia, and Queen Anne neighborhoods with an emphasis on providing this training to under-represented and low-income residents.  The event will be held on Saturday, October 6 at 1:00 pm at Swedish Hospital in Ballard, 5350 Tallman Avenue NW, in conference Rooms ABC.   Outreach and marketing efforts will focus on the target population. Those receiving the training are asked to advise their neighbors of their newly aquired skill.

Organization Name: World Kulturz dba Native Kulturz Group
Project Description: This is a project to survey people living in the High Point neighborhood that will ask residents what they would do to build, cultivate,and sustain relationships with their diverse neighbors,new and old, and with local service providers.  Volunteers will distribute, collect analyze the survey,and assist with the final report presentation event located at the High Point Neighborhood House,6400 sylvan Way SW, September 20, 6pm-9pm.

There is a new Castle Garden in South Lake Union. Utilizing an existing plot designated for children within the Cascade P-Patch, the design consists of planters that resemble a castle and a matching border. Plants are being added to the tower like planters and surrounding grounds so that they will be full of edible and flowering plants that provide delightful experiences for children and families who live, work, or play in our neighborhood. This NMF Small Sparks Fund project extends the recent work of the community (the castle garden construction and planting) by adding complementary programming as well as ongoing physical improvement, making the most out of the Castle Garden’s potential for engaging children in gardening and connecting neighborhood families to each other and our diverse community.

On Saturday, November 17th from 1:00-4:00 pm there will be a community organizing event at the Bitter Lake Community Center, 13035 Linden Ave North, promoting the `Return To Playland Days`.  From 1930-1961, Playland was Seattle's premier amusement destination along the shores of Bitter Lake; The `Fun House` a roller rink, water rides, a speedway and a dance hall provided fun for people from all walks of life.  This event will guage the interest of the neighbors and business community in bringing this community treasure back to life.  There will be food, historical exhibits, and entertainment for all ages.  The event is free and open to the public.

Community leaders in Georgetown will receive first aid training provided by the City's SNAP program.  First aid kits will be purchased and placed in the community to be available for use in responding to emergencies.

Our 2012 Harvest Social potluck and music event will occur November 23 from 5- 9 pm at the Rainier Beach Community Club at 6038 S. Pilgrim St. We hope to attract 250-300 neighbors and this event will be a good opportunity to sign them on as volunteers for our 2013 community improvement projects.

The Lake City Greenways project will bring attention to the need for safe, healthy streets for all ages and modes of transportation.  Greenways are off-arterial routes that can be safely travelled by those on foot, bicycles or in wheelchairs; cars are allowed but do not dominate.  Ideally, greenways connect neighborhoods to local businesses and civic facilities.  A  community meeting is planned for Saturday, February 17th at the Lake City Public Library, 12501 – 28th Avenue NE from 3:00-5:00pm.  Folks will have an opportunity to gain information, network and outline next steps.
Tools will be purchased and used for designing and maintaining the dirt jumps located at the Greenlake BMX bike course at Lower Woodland.

The project will fund the printing and mailing of postcards to all Wedgwood residents informing them of upcoming community summer events, including the Wedgwood Art Festival, Sustainable NE Seattle's Planet: HOME festival, and the WCC's Outdoor Cinema.

Project Title: Start-up and Outreach for Initial Membership
Project Description:
We are starting a Timebank for the Central District of Seattle.  A Timebank is a group of neighbors and volunteers that provide services for one another in exchange for `time` credit that can be used to accept services from other members.  It is a way to increase positive interactions between neighbors and build community resilience.

A steering committee of community volunteers has been meeting for over six months to establish initial policies, action plans, and other parameters for the timebank based on what other community timebanks have done as well as our own understanding of our community.

We are at the point for direct outreach into the community to build timebank membership, and for this purpose we seek a supporting grant from the Department of Neighborhoods.
Provide workshops for South Sudanese immigrants and refugees to learn basic computer skills in oder to access basic survival services in Seattle.

Project Title: Asset Based Community Development Training for Belltown
Organization Name: Belltown CC/ABCD Training Event Steering Committee
Project Description: Provide an Asset Based Community Development training event, free and open to public, to spur collaboration across/among various segments of Belltown population. Event has both educational as well as network/relational value, with potential for building bridges between diverse community leaders, residents, and organizations. The training will take place at City University on Saturday, March 9 from 9 am to 4 pm.

The Neighborhood Resource Project will create a resource guide/pamphlet and a supplemental magnet including helpful community and contact information. It will serve the purpose of welcoming all residents to the neighborhood. These will be distributed to all neighbors and/or residents of the University Park and Roosevelt Neighborhoods.

Beacon: A Hill of Beans! will engage neighbors in growing fresh food for their table and the community.  The kick-off event will be a `Bean Bonanza` on Saturday, April 20, 2013 from 1-4pm at the Jefferson Community Center, 3801 Beacon  Avenue South.  Activities include storytelling, games, haiku contest, beanbag toss and more. The project also includes a bean demonstration garden at Jefferson Community Center stewarded by local teens and free seeds for community growers.   The business district will host pots of scarlett runners, making Beacon Ave a seasonal `Boulevard of Beans`.  To close out the project an old fashioned bean supper will be hosted in the fall where neighbors will compare growing experiences, and the Beautiful Bean photo contest winner will be announced.

Funds will be used to support a one day Spring Clean event in the area around Rainier Avenue S and S Genesee on May 5.  Outreach will be conducted to neighbors and businesses to invite their participation in the clean-up.

Window Farming Advocacy will host a special event for the downtown community that focuses on educating residents in the downtown Seattle area about techniques of window farming for apartment dwellers and a educational component on Eco-literacy. The event will occur on May 25, 12 - 5 pm at 1423 1st Ave and will be open to the general public.

Project Title: Engaging Queen Anne in Safe Streets for All
Project Description: Queen Anne Greenways proposes a summer of engagement including a debut at the Queen Anne Helpline Fun Run/Walk on July 13, three days at the Queen Anne Farmers Market June 6, July 18,and August 22 plus two additional outreach activities at the local Trader Joe's and Ken's Market grocery stores. Educational interactive booths will provide opportunities to engage residents about our proposed Queen Anne Greenway which follows the historic Queen Anne Boulevard and is part of the City's Bike Master Plan Update. The project focuses on safe pedestrians and bicycling in the neighborhood while building a connected community.

Project Title: Mother's Day Parade: Act Now for Women and Kids
Project Description: The Mother's Day Parade will bring together a multiracial assembly of parents, children, feminists, unionists, people of faith, service agencies, peace activists, immigrants and others in a fun and family-friendly procession calling for comprehensive childcare, ending domestic violence, stopping deportations, and finding progressive solutions to funding jobs, public schools and social services. The parade will take place on Beacon Hill and will especially draw community members from Beacon Hill, Rainier Valley and West Seattle.

The Leschi Community Council in collaboration with the business community will host an Art Walk from Lakeside Avenue S. to 200 Lake Washington Blvd. South on Saturday, June 8th from 11:00 am - 4:00 pm.  Along with highlighting artists and businesses in the Leschi neighborhood, there will be entertainment and activities for children.  The event is free and open to the public. The Leschi Community Council is responsible for obtaining all applicable permits. Copies must be provided to the Department of Neighborhoods at least 1 week prior to the event.  Matching Fund suport is provided on a one time only basis.

Concord Elementary School students, family, and community members are producing a tiled mural that will act as a welcoming beacon onto the newly renovated playground. The mural will depict the life cycle of Salmon in the Duwamish River along with local plants and animals. The mural will be a visual invitation to entice young people to explore the newly built play areas. The mural provides an opportunity to use the process of making art to create dialog between generations and cultures.

Project Title: GAME Capacity Building and Leadership Training
Project Description: Our project is a two day workshop for building the capacity of GAME (Guiding Academic Motivation for Excellence). GAME is an independent non-profit in-school and after-school programming organization, serving at-risk youth and families, anchored in Southeast Seattle.  The workshop will focus on recruiting new board members and developing a strategic plan.  This workshop is based on recommendations from our recent `Organizational Audit and Assessment`. The proposed days of our retreat are July 13 and July 17, 2013.

The West African Community Council is hosting a citywide gathering on Saturday, August 17th from 6:00-8:00 pm at 1528 Valentine Place South.  The goal of the meeting is to discuss the needs assessment survey that will be accomplished over the next several months.  Volunteers from all 16 West African countries will hand deliver the survey to their community members and work together to assess the results.  A final report will be developed and shared that identifies the community's priorities, needs and interests.

Project Title: Jackson Park P-Patch: Outdoor Furniture Project
Project Description: This $913 grant is requested to fund new outdoor furniture in the Jackson Park P-Patch picnic area to be used by the community and gardeners in the P-Patch, including gardeners with disabilities.

The goal of the Pike Place Urban Garden is to create and promote a food system that benefits the local low-income Market Community while strengthening relationships through nutrition, wellness and education.  To ensure the success of this effort classes in basic gardening skills will be offered to the community.  Produce harvested this season will be donated to the Pike Market Senior Center’s Meal Program and to the Pike Market Food Bank.

Project Title: National Night Out Neighborhood Block Party
Project Description: We are hosting our 2nd National Night Out Block Party in our neighborhood on August 6, 2013 from 6:00-9:00pm. This is our second year hosting the event. This year our event will include entertainment and a barbecue. We also sponsor monthly ice cream socials and our sense of community continues to be well received by our Cedar Park neighbors.

Project Title: 2013 Cascade National Night Out Block Party
Project Description: We will re-new one of the best National Night Out block parties in all of Seattle. The event will be on August 6, 2013 from 6:00-9:00pm.  It will be very postive for kids to witness and interact with police officers and firemen, volunteers,and organizers. We plan on a serious conversation about safety in our neighborhood.

Nihonmachi Nite, an event on August 10, 2013 will serve to promote Japantown and its rich culture by showcasing live cultural performances, food, shops, galleries, and family friendly activities. The event takes place from 4:00 pm to 8:00 pm on South Main Street between 5th Avenue South and 6th Avenue South

Funds will be used to purchase magnets and develop outreach materials promoting the Phinney Ridge Community Council.  Magnets and printed information will be distributed by volunteers at numerous Night Out block parties.

Project Title: Neighborhood Night Out Member Recruitment Activity
Project Description: During the neighborhood Night Out on August 6, 2013, the Roosevelt Neighborhood Association (RNA) will promote involvement in the RNA through a member drive. They will do this by visiting each block party in the Roosevelt neighborhood and providing RNA membership materials, conducting a neighborhood survey, raising awareness, and facilitating a game to encourage neighbors to learn who is living near them.

Project Title: A Meeting in an Unlikely Place
Project Description: This project explores ways to merge dance and architecture by the use of performance installations and is part of an effort to activate Nord Alley.  The performance piece is entitled A Meeting in an Unlikely Place. This work takes place in Nord Alley August 1, 2013 and will be free to the public. There will be a built installation exhibited for the day with performances at 6pm, 7pm, 8pm and 9pm each lasting approximately 10-12 minutes.

Project Title: Neighborhood Night Out - Block Party & Potluck
Project Description: All area neighborhood residents are invited to attend the Night Out event on the evening of August 4, 2015 from 5:00pm to 10:00pm. The 1300 block of NE 43rd Street will be closed between University Way NE to the east and the mid-block alley to the west.

The Victory Heights Community Council is excited to to continue to build community in our area by organizing a neighborhood-wide National Night Out celebration on the street next to the Victory Heights Park (1700 and 1800 Block of NE 106th Street). As incentive for great attendance, we will provide a free dessert (build your own sundaes) along with toys and games for kids that attend. One of the most important issues facing our community at this time is crime and a night out event will help build a safer area.  Event will be held Tuesday, August 6, 2013 from 6:00-8:00pm.

PACE participants will work with Rainier Valley Greenways to host a pop-up greenway event on Sunday, April 6, 2014 from 11:00am-2:00pm in the 3800 block of S Ferdinand St.  The event will highlight the benefits and the need for pedestrian and bicycle friendly areas in southeast Seattle.

Project Title: Small Spark Grant for Night Out 2013
Project Description: We will host a Night Out event on the 6900 Block of Flora Ave S on Tuesday, August 6, 2013. Funding will be used to purchase food as well as arts and crafts supplies for group activities. This event is a great opportunity to engage with our neighbors and families and also a great way to prevent crime. We have had to deal with continues crime in our neighborhood, specifically the 6900 block, from a Chronic Nuisance Motel. This is a chance to have our neighbors safely visit our block without feeling threatened.

Project Title: Olympic Hills Pocket Park Block Party Outreach
Project Description: Lake City Greenways is working with SDOT to create a pocket park in a street end in the Olympic Hills neighborhood (NE 133rd between 27th Ave NE and 28th Ave NE). Night Out on Tuesday, August 6th will be used as an occasion for outreach to the Olympic Hills neighborhood regarding this proposal. Volunteers will visit all of the gatherings in the community distributing information and soliciting input on the project.

Project Title: North Beacon Hill Neighbors Night Out Block Party
Project Description: Our neighborhood's annual Night Out Block Party continues to grow steadily every year. It will be held on August 6, 2013 from 6:00-9:00pm.  Last year we had about 70-80 people. This year we expect over 100.  We've booked a band and are getting a port-a-potty. We plan to increase the diversity in the attendance which will make a better event.

Organization Name: Night Out Rainier Beach So Seattle
Project Description: The Rainier Beach community will be hosting a Night Out Event for the 8th Consecutive Year, on Tuesday, August 6th from 5:30 - 8:30 pm in the 8300 block of Wabash Avenue South.  There will be a neighborhood BBQ and music from a local band. Seattle Tilth will showcase their new location and programs and Sustainability Works will have a resource table to share information about energy efficiency. Neighborhood Matching Fund supported events are free, open to the public and funded on a one time only basis.

The Cherry Hill Community Council hosts the annual Night Out event which includes kids games, entertainment and food. The focus will be to develop block watch groups in our community 14th Ave and 18th Ave between E Union and E Cherry. Night Out is on Tuesday, August 6, 2013

`From Hiroshima to Hope`(FHTH) is an annual event held at Green Lake Park since 1985 on August 6, the date of the World War II atomic bombing of Hiroshima, Japan.  FHTH is a coalition of organizations and individuals promoting world peace, non-violence and nuclear disarmament.  Paper lanterns inscribed in Japanese calligraphy in the Toro Nagashi tradition carry messages of remembrance, hope and world peace and are set out onto Green Lake in a program of inspirational speakers and music.  Expected atendance is 500-1,000 people.

Organization Name: Peoples Family Life Center: Work-It-Out Seattle
Project Description: Our Night Out project will bring together neighbors to learn about crime prevention,and how we can keep our neighborhood safe, and a beautification project for the neighborhood.  We will sweep, gather leaves and waste collected, and reclaim two traffic circles that need digging out, weeding and replanting -  at 24th/E. Fir Street and 24th/E. Spruce Street.  The event will occur August 6, 2013 from 5:00 - 9:00pm

Project Title: National Night Out Belltown Block Picnic
Organization Name: Belltown Citizens on Patrol, Belltown Community Council
Project Description: In conjuction with Night Out on August 6, groups in Belltown are celebrating the opening of the first block of the Bell Street Park on Bell Street between 1st and 2nd Avenues between 6:00 - 9:00 p.m.  The project will strengthen the sense of community by involving local Belltown business, neighbors, MID, and SPD, Belltown Citizens on Patrol, Belltown Community Council and local entertainers and will help develop a sense of community amongst the different groups.

The 900 block of 21st Avenue, between E. Union and E. Marion Streets, is a collection of Central District citizens from many backgrounds, cultures, generations, and with many interests. Night Out is an opportunity to celebrate that diversity and strengthen those neighborhood connections. A gathering is planned for Tuesday, August 6, from 6 - 9:00 pm.  This year's event will include activities for children, performances from local artists and musicians, and great food from neighborhood chefs and restaurant owners. Neighborhood Matching Fund supported events are free, open to the public and funded on a one time only basis.

The `Pop-up-Greenway` will be a temporary installation between NW 60th and NW 80th simulating potential elements of a greenway created in a corridor currently used by walkers and bike riders in the Phinney/Greenwood neighborhood. The installation will take place on August 9 to coincide with a Summer Streets event along Greenwood Avenue North and will remain in place for approximately two weeks.  The project will allow neighbors to experience a greenway and feel its effects firsthand. The project will include education and outreach to neighbors and opportunities for public comments.  A website will be created as one component of the outreach strategy and to provide a vehicle for providing feedback.

The Friends of 19th and Madison Park will be  hosting a Night Out event at that location on Tuesday, August 6, 2013 from 6-9:00 pm.  There will be a variety of fun activities for children and adults as well as great food and conversation.  The goal is to promote crime prevention awareness, to bring together people who live in the neighborhood, and to update the community on the development of the new park. Neighborhood Matching Fund supported events are free, open to the public and funded on a one time only basis.

As part of the City of Seattle's participation in the National Night Out Against Crime 2013, the Letitia Neighborhood Group (LNG) will host an open block party on the evening of August 6, 2013 at Letitia Ave S and S Geneesee St from 6:00pm-8:00pm.  For the party we will provide information about city departments who can help us maintain our safety and enhance our surroundings.

For the 2013 Night Out on Tuesday August 6, 2013 from 8:00pm - 12:00am the `Friends of 2nd Avenue` are planning a multi-venue celebration, with food, music, performances, `Safety Discussions` and more.
